output: Mr. President, Mr. President, Madam Vice President, the Commission appears to be acting like a distracted student who is frantically trying to make up for lost time before submitting their work.
Certainly, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be seen as a step towards the Commission addressing social issues.

The President of the Commission failed to grasp the gravity of the warning issued by citizens in France, the Netherlands, and Ireland, which would unfortunately have been identical elsewhere had a popular vote been held.
These elections are calls to order.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a social project and not just to adopt even more technical directives.
Internal market regulation is indeed necessary, but it is far from being the entirety of the matter.
The 2009 program, like its predecessors, will miss the point.
Citizens do not expect the Commission to limit itself to merely completing, or even simplifying, legislation.
They await for the Commission to rise to the challenge assigned to it by the treaties, to be the locomotive, the think tank of the Union.
It is not enough for its president to be wise and silent, standing at attention behind the Council President.
We expect the Commission to act as a key player in reflecting on the nature of the societal project we need.
But what is the social project outlined in this program?
The 2009 program does not contain any major errors, but it is not the program our fellow citizens need.
Mr. President, it will be up to the new college to assume its responsibilities.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the calls of the people than the current one.
Mr. President, firstly, a question to the Council.

the guide for the high-level conference on Georgia, which had been proposed by the French Presidency, and how the current Presidency of the Union intends to uphold Georgia's territorial integrity, given that a country recognizes two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
But it is a shame that Mr. Barroso is not here because, in his speech, he was not convincing, perhaps because he himself is not convinced by the proposals he presented to us.
I believe that the financial and economic situation is far more serious than he described to us.
Even today, I believe that those who monitor the internet can see clearly that stock markets continue to collapse despite interventions.

This is truly, for me, the collapse of the current system, a completely obsolete system, the system that has led to bankruptcy, that has led to land being completely exploited and choked by greenhouse gas emissions, that has caused underdevelopment in the Global South and that has caused urban decay in our cities.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the current financial crisis clearly demonstrates that, when the problem is global, a global response is required.
And it is true, especially in the field of agriculture or in the food sector.
This is why we have created, among other things, the World Trade Organization, which we agree upon, and which seeks to establish globalized rules.

It turns out that it does not quite work as we would like it to, because we are faced with a problem: we need to reconcile two things. Everyone agrees on the necessity of free trade, but equally necessary are the protections that must accompany it.
and the protection of national economies or agricultures, this does not equate to protectionism.
To achieve this, the path we have followed for 60 years, since the GATT, is an imbalanced one that moves towards the reduction of tariffs with the goal of their eventual elimination.
It turns out that, technically, reducing customs duties
It is quite difficult, as evidenced by a whole series of mathematical formulas, the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn't work properly because the product is not unitary.
It is composed of numerous elements with very different rules of origin, and technically reducing customs duties is not as simple as one might think.
We find ourselves in a technical impasse and are attempting, politically, through negotiations, to break free from this deadlock.
Now, it turns out that, technologically, a new customs technology has been invented: the technology of customs duties deductible by the exporter from the economy of the importing state.
In practice, this deductible customs duty is converted into a customs credit equal to the amount of duty the exporter has paid in the importing country.
This three-character customs credit is refundable, negotiable, and grant-eligible.
It is reimbursable when the exporter makes a purchase from the importer; he can deduct the customs duty he has incurred.

It is negotiable because, if the exporting company that has paid one hundred percent of customs duties has nothing to buy from the importer, it negotiates without customs credit on the stock market or in banks.
It is incentivizable if we wish to assist developing countries, the importer, in offering an amount of customs credit greater than the amount of customs duty.
Well, with this technique, we create an international trading currency whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would provide 13 billion euros of international currency in the trade sector.

Mr. President, the Russo-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis have provided an opportunity for the European Union to assert itself on the global stage as a full-fledged and leading political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has succeeded in uniting and finding coordinated, effective, and rapid responses.
In the face of crises, Europe proves its existence and demonstrates its added value.
In the realm of immigration, for instance, the every-man-for-himself approach was no longer applicable.
The adoption by the European Council of the Pact on Immigration and Asylum, initiated by the French presidency, represents a significant step forward.
In the fight against climate change, Europe must set itself concrete objectives and show the way to its global partners.

You have already expressed your opinion on this matter, Mr. President of the Council, but we wish for this agreement to be as balanced as possible, as it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which are currently greatly destabilized.
but also to ask ourselves the question of the type of development we will choose for the future.
To meet the challenges ahead, the European Union needs the Lisbon Treaty more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must present us with a solution at the December European Council, many of us are demanding it.
In recent weeks, we have proudly observed a strong political Europe, united in adversity, determined in the face of its partners, and listened to on the international stage.
We hope that this new European mindset will become the norm and endure.
The Lisbon Treaty is the best solution we have to achieve this.
Madam President, Mr. Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan, and of course, I pay tribute to him for acting swiftly and managing to stop the war.
But this war is somewhat our failure. For fourteen years, we have been timid, silently witnessing the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions.

This war, indeed, has awakened Europe by confronting it with its responsibilities, but the fire continues to smoulder in the Caucasus and we must do everything in our power to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all Europe.
I am also aware, Minister, of the divisions among European countries regarding Georgia's entry into NATO, and personally, I am opposed to it.
I will make a proposal: I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these Caucasian countries.
Only the status of neutrality will be able to ease tensions with Russia and definitively prevent this subregion from new conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own security.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, over the last three days, the European Development Days have taken place, where there was extensive discussion of the food crisis that is severely affecting the poorest countries.
All interventions emphasized the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by optimally utilizing their land and natural resources.

In passing, the lyrical pronouncements of those who called yesterday and still today for a reduction in state intervention and public spending, for the liberalization of all of Asia, for privatization, and for the marginalization of agriculture.
This quasi-prehistoric activity, this about-face in favor of massive public investments in agricultural production and food sovereignty, was at once both comical and scandalous.
The future of agriculture in developing countries is directly related to the debate we are having today.

Alas, I do not feel that this health check of the CAP, initiated before the peak of the food riots and the disastrous market turmoil, takes into account the situation of the peasantry in the Global South and draws all the conclusions from the serious ecological, social, economic, and financial crises we are experiencing today.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between farmers in the North and South is so little addressed, both in the Commission's proposals and in the Parliament's report, and the questioning of the promised one billion euros shows how much further the journey still has to go.
Mr. President, the report we are to vote on tomorrow represents the culmination of a year's work and negotiations dedicated to the future of the Common Agricultural Policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was on November 20th that Ms. Fischer Boel came to present her proposals on the health check.
Following the progress report by Lutz Goebbels, here is the report by Capula Santo on the Commission's proposal.
Our two colleagues should be congratulated for their excellent work.
The Agriculture Committee of the European Parliament managed to remain firm in the face of the Commission's initial proposals, which we deemed far too liberal.
Madam President, I will remain vigilant with regard to the dairy sector and, in particular, the measures preceding the abolition of quotas.
I am particularly thinking of mountain milk producers, who must not become the poor relations of this reform. Care must be taken not to overlook them, as they will need more support than others.
I do not want to speculate, but how can one envision the French dairy industry consolidated within a single region?
It is therefore with kindness that I welcome the proposal to establish a milk fund and the one to assess, as early as 2010, the increase in milk quotas according to market developments.

Mr. President, the calculation of the progressive modulation carried out by the Agriculture Committee seems fair to me and would allow us to enhance territorial development, rural areas, and sustainably preserve biodiversity.
I also commend the clarification of eco-conditionality, whose implementation had been a real headache for farmers until now.

I also hope that we maintain the tobacco fund amount that allows us to keep our small holdings in Europe, as well as a not insignificant workforce in a region where nothing else can be exploited, and which enables us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Mr. Minister, we greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have demonstrated a great deal of patience and determination, and you have unwaveringly dedicated your time without fail.
It was a true pleasure to work alongside you.
You will have, with us, been highly efficient.
I know that we can count on
Mr. President, first of all, thank you for the work accomplished and the conclusions and orientations proposed by the CAP health check, as presented in Mr. Cabulos Santos' report.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond solely to market signals.
Its activity has impacts, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but also, as we all too often see, on territories and employment.
The removal of market instruments would be a severe blow to our agriculture.

Decoupling, for instance, poses a real challenge for certain livestock-rearing territories, such as those with suckler cows and sheep, and I am pleased to have heard Mrs Fischer Boel address this issue earlier.
Moreover, it is clear that strictly adhering to historical references would impose a significant constraint on any possibility of reform.

However, I still believe that the issue of the second pillar of the CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) is essential, as rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in the countryside.
Therefore, we need to consider this issue of the second foot without, of course, amputating the first.
Given that Minister Jouillet is about to leave us, I believe this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most diligent ministers we have ever known.
I wish him/her good luck.

Madam President, I voted for the Perisch report on the integration of Oceania 20 into a single Oceania, and I must say that I did so with a heavy heart, because I believe that this single Oceania does not represent a simplification and does not enhance transparency.
It will complicate life for viticulturists and the entire wine industry.
Last night, the commissioner tried to reassure us.
I hope that the Commission will keep its word and, above all, that the profession will continue to be adequately represented on the advisory committee, as has been the case since the first WTO.
He is a true gentleman.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act project presented to us by the Commission last June.

Certainly, as early as the 2000s, initiatives were launched targeting SMEs, and I particularly think of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Vlastoo on the SME charter. These initiatives were appreciated but deemed insufficient because they often remained mere pious hopes.
Today, we must go further.
The severe economic crisis that our countries are going through, with consequences that are particularly worrying for SMEs, underscores this point if further evidence were needed.
In this regard, the Small Business Act represents a new, decidedly proactive approach.
In a few weeks, we will be examining Mrs Herzog's report on the Commission communication, but today, through the submission of this oral question, we have sought to call on the Council.
Sir, we have noted with interest the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and would like to know if the European Council of December 11th and 12th next will...
will duly note its conclusions and give a strong impetus to ensure that the major guiding principle think small first is rapidly transposed into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We hope that the Council will commit to the principle of the action plan annexed hereto, along with concrete measures.
In this regard, and given the short time allotted to me, I will emphasize three areas in which we need compelling impetus.
Impact assessments, which should be systematic, and regular monitoring, with oversight by the European Parliament, of the implementation status of the Small Business Act in the Member States.
access to public markets
The code of good conduct has no binding effect. Together, we need to be more imaginative and inventive, and propose concrete, tailored measures that genuinely open up these markets to SMEs.
Finally, access to financing, more essential than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are good, Minister, they must also include support for the supply.
There is an urgent need.
Thank you for assuring us of the Council's willingness.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, as they employ over 70% of the EU's workforce and account for 99% of European businesses.

But, as has already been stated, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now being troubled and threatened by the financial crisis, because it erodes purchasing power and consumer confidence, affecting order books.

It is therefore the cash flow of SMEs that is at risk, and it is essential to ensure support for their activities by making sure that banks guarantee effective access to the financing necessary for the continuity of their operations.
The entire focus is on the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council on December 1st, which the Minister mentioned, and the recovery plan approved by the European finance ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority for the Union is essential, and I would like to commend the action plan in support of the Small Business Act for Europe.
It indeed translates the will to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle of giving priority to the smallest first, that is, to European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner stated and as we all say, the Council must truly engage with the other institutions.
European Union, for this principle to now become effective, it is necessary to go beyond the declaration stage, to move towards implementation in all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan is a genuine response to the urgency of the situation.
And I would like to commend, Mr. Minister, the determination of the French Presidency of the Union, which enabled the rapid translation of intentions into actions.

Mr. President, Madam President-in-Office, Commissioner, I offer my full support to the rapporteur who is defending the position we held at first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
Mr. President, it was urgent to align our legislation on working time with the case law of the Court of Justice, and this has been done.
The CERCAS report provides balanced and protective responses for employees.
All childcare time is counted as working time.
Compensatory rest takes place immediately following the service period.
It is a matter of common sense to ensure decent working conditions, especially for medical professions.
But the reform of the working time directive also gives us the opportunity to advance our European social law by abolishing individual opt-outs.
The CERCAS report seizes this opportunity and proposes a gradual elimination of any possibility of derogation from the maximum legal working time.
One must face reality head-on.
It is a joke to say that the employee is in a position of equality with their employer and can refuse what is offered to them.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly demonstrate to the governments of the Member States that the text they wish to impose on us is unacceptable.

In the chorus of praise that will undoubtedly ring in the ears of the French government from tomorrow, it seems necessary to me to focus first and foremost on the employees who will be called upon to work ever more without truly having a choice, and this is true for all those who will be asked to work on Sundays in France.
It is, moreover, clearly to open this possibility that the French government has changed its stance on individual opt-out at the Council.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, let us listen to the employees and attempt to respond to their appeal if we do not wish for the negative votes of the French, Dutch, and Irish referendums to be followed by many more, calling into question a European Union that would make them feel their daily issues are not being addressed.
Mr. President, it was a very fine French presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices to disagree.
The twenty-seven set aside their differences to reach a series of decisions that were exemplary.
On the energy-climate package, Europe is taking a first step, and in this regard, this first step is immense.
She now has the means to fulfill her environmental responsibility without sacrificing her economy.
From now on, it can take the lead in this area to guide other continents towards sustainable development.
Moreover, Ireland offers a scenario to emerge from its isolation.
Our Irish friends will once again pronounce themselves on the Lisbon Treaty with all the cards in hand, since practically all the other members will have definitively pronounced themselves.
The current crises demonstrate that the Union needs the best institutional tools more than ever to be effective.
The European Council has adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan, based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the industrial sectors hardest hit.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of reducing certain VAT rates, and I fully share his viewpoint.
Let us hope that the ministers of economy and finance will reach an agreement in March that seemed impossible to the heads of state and government last weekend.
The challenges facing Europeans provide an opportunity for the Union to reveal itself to them as more united, more responsive, and more concerned with their protection.
We are grateful to the French Presidency for having initiated this new dynamic.
We, like Nicolas Sarkozy, hope not to see again anytime soon the councils of yesterday that ended at four in the morning to negotiate three peanuts.
Over the last six months, Europe has indeed changed in terms of mindset, scope, and credibility.
We must thank the French Presidency; we are well aware that it is not entirely unrelated.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
what we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.
But we are calling on the Security Council to take a stand, for the bodies to take a stand, for the European Union to take a stand, and here in Parliament we discuss and refuse to take a stand.

I believe that, given the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of the utmost importance for this Parliament to take a stance and clearly state its position on how to halt the massacres currently taking place in the Middle East.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and clarity to vote on a resolution following our debate.
That is why our group is requesting a revision of the Conference of Presidents' decision and the conclusion of the debate that we have, that we must have.
We must address the situation in Gaza through a resolution that demonstrates this Parliament's clear and firm position, by a majority, to halt the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution, and we must be aware that we have a political responsibility regarding what is happening. This political responsibility cannot merely be a discussion; it must be a resolution that clearly states what we stand for and what we condemn.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, now more than ever, the directive proposal that Parliament is about to vote on evokes in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that the rapporteur, Mr Klinz, has been engaged in a long-term effort for years and has negotiated with talent, particularly during the trilogue.

It is also true that the directive includes a number of significant advancements, aimed at improving the functioning of the internal market and the collective management of financial assets, and has been welcomed as such by the European investment fund industry.

It remains that the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament were never entirely free, as the outcome was known in advance. For certain stakeholders, it was imperative, at all costs, to introduce the European passport for management companies.
In principle, there is little to criticize; the passport is entirely defensible. However, it is essential to ensure the introduction of the passport for management companies.
It is accompanied by the necessary guarantees, particularly in terms of fund oversight, as it leads to a separation of functions across borders.
Now, I regretfully note that the system in place is not only complex, but it is also subject to divergent interpretations.
It risks encountering practical difficulties very quickly, which will harm the European export finance industry, particularly exports to third countries.
I have duly noted that my position is in the minority, however, I do not feel uncomfortable.
In normal times, I would have been tempted to say that only practice will allow for definitive conclusions in this matter and thus determine.
Who is right between those who trust in the adaptive capabilities of market actors and those who adhere to a more cautious approach?
It is not excluded that success may be at the end, but, on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
However, very recent events, notably the Madoff scandal and its implications for the financial asset management industry, are not reassuring.
Scepticism gives way to my anxiety.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, as we are already witnessing.
Fundamental reevaluations may be necessary in this context of crisis.
In this context of deep crisis, making choices that dilute the responsibilities of the actors or that presume perfect cooperation between regulatory authorities can indeed be seen as an incongruity.
I tell you, as I believe, this directive is also one from a bygone era before the crisis.
She is marked by a certain nonchalance.
Indeed, the financial system is set to endure a profound and fundamental crisis of confidence, necessitating a complete rethinking of entire sectors of its architecture.

Let us not forget that the primary function of OPCM (Organismes de Placement Collectif en Immobilier) is investor protection through risk diversification and the establishment of strict rules. By voting for this text as it stands, without truly knowing where we are heading, we are acting as if nothing has happened.
This autism bodes ill, which is why I will abstain, even though I have signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances and the improvements made, it seems to me that we have given little consideration to the principles I have just explained.

Mr. President, although the regulation on animal reporting has been in force since January 2007, it appears that Member States are not systematically complying by providing annual reports as requested.
Thus, a comprehensive analysis remains random, as many elements are lacking regarding the resources deployed to conduct inspections.
Mr. President, as a member of animal protection associations and of the animal defense intergroup, this topic concerns me greatly.
Associations have been fighting desperately for decades, only achieving the establishment of guidelines in this area in 2007, where Member States have shown a certain degree of leniency.
I would even go so far as to say a certain degree of bad faith, because, after all, we know that implementing controls and inspections is by no means insurmountable.
We know the slaughterhouse locations, we know the breeding sites, we are aware of the livestock transit routes, so where is the issue?

I believe it is important, in our time when public opinion is increasingly aware, and rightly so, of animal welfare, whether in terms of breeding, slaughter, or transport conditions, that states respect these sentiments.

Given the opportunity to speak, I would like to add, regarding transportation, that it would be indispensable to consider and take into account, independently of travel times, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a several-hour journey in the Netherlands in the spring is hardly comparable to the same journey time in midsummer in a country like Greece.
Shouldn't night-time transportation be mandated in these latter cases?
I thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

Madam President, I am delighted that it was a Briton, our colleague Parrish, who tabled this text, which shows that the Romanian soldiers, two years ago, were right to go to Great Britain and bring amphoras of olive oil and wine.
But then, two consequences must be drawn from this.

It is not very reasonable, symbolically, to locate the Food Agency in Helsinki, and it is not reasonable for the European Commission not to reverse the following decisions: firstly, to restore aid for almond trees, and secondly, to stop.

Stop the attacks on olive trees, particularly in Andalusia and across Europe. Halt the assaults on red tuna fishermen in the Mediterranean and the encroachment on European vineyards through land purchases.
I suggest to our commissioner, our president, Mr. Barroso, that he organize a grand banquet in Portugal featuring sheep's cheese and wine.
Mr. President, indeed we have all campaigned for the closure of Guantanamo, and we have all applauded President Obama's decision to shut down this prison of shame.
Today, the question of accepting the detainees from Guantanamo should not be one that we have to consider.
As Europeans committed to our values of upholding human rights, we must take responsibility, for it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
One has been able to read, and here I am addressing the Council, one has been able to read in the press that some Member States were not particularly enthusiastic about this reception.
Here, I would like to make a sincere appeal to the Council and, in particular, to the reluctant Member States to agree to receive these detainees on their territory.

And I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst thing would be for the strong momentum generated by the closure of Guantnamo to fizzle out because we would not have stepped up when Europe was called upon.

This is important, as the European animal feed sector constitutes one of the most significant segments of agriculture, both in terms of production, accounting for half of the European Union's agricultural output (120 million tonnes), and in terms of revenue, generating approximately 50 billion euros.
The European Union indeed counts five million breeders and sixty million households owning pets.
In the past, the European Union has had to deal with several health crises, which means that today we must be more vigilant about transparency to meet the expectations of both farmers and consumers.

The provisions outlined in this report have the advantage of incurring minimum costs for industries and providing significant benefits to consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they purchase.
Adopting this report will help mitigate risks by ensuring improved product quality, enhanced control, better traceability, and comprehensive information for breeders, and ultimately, consumers.
Today, with the increase in international trade, it is more than imperative to strengthen all preventive measures to ensure that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not recur.

Mr. President, this report succeeds in balancing the right to information, while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must mandatorily appear on labels, with the right to intellectual property, so crucial for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

Mr. President, I believe that, indeed, manufacturers should be required to immediately notify the use of any new raw material included in the composition of animal feed, in order to ensure transparency and facilitate the control carried out by the competent authorities.
Including an emergency procedure that allows for the addition of a new dangerous substance to the list of prohibited materials seems to me to be absolutely essential.

Similarly, allowing breeders the option to consult the competent national authority or the European Commission in cases of doubt about an unfair allegation enables a greater variety of systems, protects the customer while preserving the fairness of commercial transactions.

I would like to offer my full support to this excellent report, as experience has shown that regulation of pet food labeling, emphasizing quality, transparency, traceability, and control, is the best way to prevent future health crises in Europe.

Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, nor its High Representative for Foreign Policy Javier Solana, former Secretary General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
At most, they are called upon to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they are doing today for Kosovo, Lebanon, or Afghanistan.
Americans and Israelis bomb, Europeans fund the reconstruction.
Such is the division of labor among allies.
Now, it should be the vandals who pay.
Egypt is at the center of peace talks focusing on an extended ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge to be met is formidable insofar as the new Israeli government, under pressure from the third man, Lieberman, leader of an extreme right wing that is democratically accepted there, risks having its task significantly complicated in these negotiations.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future Prime Minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty is that the Palestinian Authority of Mahmoud Abbas has become in the West Bank a sort of international protectorate whose legitimacy has greatly diminished among the population.

The final factor to be considered is the expansion of Israeli settlements, which has been continuous since 1967, making the establishment of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly challenging.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli court, but will the hawks on both sides accept this divine truce that both parties demand without having the means to achieve it?
Allow me to add a reflection on France's reintegration into the NATO integrated military structure, which will be up for debate with the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will impose severe obligations on France.
Indeed, we are rejoining NATO at a time when the Cold War has been over for 90 years.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of free nations.
Should the logic of blocs be reinforced in an era of multipolarization and the rise of emerging countries, including in military terms?
Moreover, France's adherence to the integrated structure will require it to increase its contingent in Afghanistan, even though it already has 3 troops deployed there.
With what budget will she fund this, given that her defense budget is set to fall below 2% of GDP and over 30 regiments are set to be disbanded?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budget contribution to join NATO while simultaneously reducing our military presence in Africa.
European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will thus be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
One only needed to read the Treaty of Lisbon and its additional protocols to be convinced of this.
Whether in terms of foreign policy or common security, the European path is a dead end that will lead only to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of national sovereignty and independence, resting in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent.
Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs for this quite remarkable synthesis they have produced of the current state of our common foreign and security policy.

Mr. High Representative, as you know better than anyone, Europe is expected on the world stage today to take the place assigned to it by its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanist values.

I am compelled to observe that, despite the regularly expressed desire of more than two-thirds of our European fellow citizens, as you mentioned, certain progress has indeed been made over the past ten years, I concede that. However, I am also compelled to note that this Europe still does not exist.
If a recent illustration were needed, his erasure in the resolution of the new drama in the Middle East would serve to demonstrate it.
There has been, and there still is, a need for a European presence in Gaza to play an active role, both in aiding the survival of the population and in the reconstruction of the territory.
countries and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had enabled the transformation of this territory into a launch base for rockets of all calibers.
Despite the fine words uttered at Charmelcher and Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done in this regard.

Mr. President, I renew here a question already posed during the Lebanese crisis: when can we, Mr. High Representative, hope to see the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we have done to counter piracy?
We have the means to do so.
Will we ever have the will to do so?
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President, dear colleagues, the Parliament's decision to accept the urgency requested by the Council for the regulation of the matter has not been made.
The handling of this file was unanimous, both in the Committee on Fisheries last week and this morning, here in the plenary session.

Indeed, we are all aware of the necessity for the European Union to uphold the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the relevant international commission, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT).
Concretely, this is about implementing the recommendations adopted by this organization to endure the persistent phenomenon of overfishing of bluefin tuna in the Atlantic.
the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean and to address the serious danger that ensues for the future of the species and thus for fishing itself.
Two of our colleagues, the Committee on Fisheries, Mrs Fraga and Mr Romeva i Rueda, were present in Marrakech and will be speaking on this subject as part of this debate.
I would like to stress, for my part, the importance our committee attaches to this file, which involves the main dimensions of the common fisheries policy, namely management.
on the resource, fleet management, compliance with international, regional, and bilateral agreements, technical measures, and above all, monitoring, which I will revisit later.
This distinctive file thus serves, in our view, as a test of the credibility of this common fisheries policy.
For this reason, it was obviously out of the question for the implementation of the new recovery plan to proceed without consultation with the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has ultimately chosen the only legally and politically acceptable path for the implementation of the agreement.
recommendations of the CETA, namely a formal proposal for a regulation under Article 37 of the Treaty.

The transposition into EU law of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union in regional fisheries organizations is indeed not a trivial matter, and we insist that it always take place under the democratic scrutiny of our institution.

In substance, I welcome the various measures proposed, which, although restrictive for our operators, are commensurate with the challenges at hand. I would like to highlight the most significant ones as follows.
The most important measures are undoubtedly those related to control, as it is indeed true that without control, no reconstitution plan can be effective.
I therefore thank you, Commissioner, for this proposal, and I invite you to show the same consideration.
determination in the concrete implementation of the plan, once it has been endorsed by the Council, that you have shown in concluding a satisfactory agreement at the level of the ICCAT.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet undertaken to concretely define territorial cohesion.
The French presidency is being tested there, and I would like to commend this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable as soon as the Lisbon Treaty enters into force, and that its parameters be clarified as soon as possible.

I hope, like the excellent report by Mr. Van Nistelrooij, that territorial cohesion will become the legal basis ensuring the harmonious development of all areas of the Union and enabling us to make the most of the specific characteristics of each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate community policies to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
Territorial cohesion is not solely intended to target regions afflicted by permanent handicaps.
It must nevertheless focus on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept seems to me to be relevant for considering the outermost regions in order to ensure their sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I thank the rapporteur for incorporating into his compromise amendments my requests concerning the specific challenges faced by the outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, indispensable elements of territorial cohesion.
Upon reading the Commission's recent communication entitled "The OUTER regions: an asset for Europe," it seems to me that it intends to apply to the outermost regions the entire set of...
recommendations concerning the improvement of governance in the area of cohesion, thus constituting the first, somewhat anticipated, illustration of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the General States of Overseas France, which will soon commence, will adopt the same approach and extensively incorporate the significant territorial impact of European policies in favor of the LPA (Least Developed Countries), the added value of which is undeniable.
irrevocable and unchallenged.
We find it amusing to read the conclusions of the presidency's last Council.
It resembles the victory statement of all defeated armies.

They have the audacity, even going so far as to repeatedly assert that, once the crisis is over, the Union will build a stronger economy for the future, or in the reaffirmation of a Lisbon strategy in complete disarray.
Thus, as they lock themselves away in their glass tower, eurocrats, europhiles, and all manner of Euro-enthusiasts eventually lose sight of reality.
Everyone knows that the eurozone was the first to enter a recession, having experienced the lowest growth rate in the world for eight years.
But it is also the one facing the greatest challenges in terms of industrial competitiveness and employment situation.
Above all, it is she who, through the general disarmament of natural defenses taken away from nations, is the least equipped to react.
In reality, the only merit of this crisis will be to awaken the peoples lulled by the ease of financial anticipation and by anti-national propaganda.
Only states will have the legitimate instruments required for any large-scale action, and to do so, they will need to break free from the constraints of the European Union and the euro.
For the French, in any case, it is increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French policy, no French policy without national and popular sovereignty.

Madam President, I believe that, indeed, the issue of food distribution to benefit the most deprived is entirely timely, but I think that, in essence, the Commission's proposal does not address the problem.

The issue of co-financing raises questions for me, and I believe that it is rather the question of liberalism that has guided the evaluations of the CAP in recent years and which should be called into question.
Riots against hunger, the drastic fluctuations in food prices are permanent indicators of the limits of the liberalization of agricultural markets.
This liberalization has always come at the expense of vulnerable populations, vulnerable producers, and fragile territories.

I therefore advocate for politics to reclaim its place, to take the lead, both at the European and global levels, and for the strategic field of agriculture and human nutrition, from both a quantitative and qualitative perspective, not to be subject to the strict laws of the market.
Indeed, there is an urgency, and the Zykerski report addresses this urgency, which I welcome. However, I hope that in the case of the debate that is now open,
For the future of the CAP, it should be recalled that the primary objective is indeed to structurally combat the hunger and poverty that we know exist in all Member States and around the world.

Rural territories are available to meet food needs through sufficient and high-quality production, but will they be provided with the financial and human resources to ensure this heavy responsibility?
Mr. President, during this period of economic recession, it was important for the European Union to continue demonstrating its solidarity with developing countries.
Let us recall that in 2007, the European Community and the Member States together contributed 60% of total development aid, making the European Union the world's largest donor.
European development funds enable the fight against poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that, for the ACP countries, a budget of 23 billion euros has been allocated for the 2008 period under the tenth EDF, which represents almost double the amount provided for the ninth EDF.
The Court of Auditors, in its report, concludes that the accounts of the 7th, 8th, and 9th European Development Funds are generally faithful, legal, and regular.
One can only applaud the record levels of contract performance and payments for the implementation of the EDF.
However, I also note that progress needs to be continued in order to strengthen the control and monitoring system, as there is still a significant level of errors affecting certain transactions.
Similarly, there is often an unacceptably high risk associated with budget support, and in my view, these risks should be better assessed.
On this matter, I concur with the view that budgetary support should only be granted if the recipient country has the capacity to manage the funds in a transparent, responsible, and effective manner.

Mr. President, among the priorities on which we must work in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the EAF (European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development) into the general budget of the Community, as this would enhance the effectiveness and transparency of development aid.

In conclusion, Mr. President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the staff of the Commission who did an excellent job on the ground, and I obviously regret the absence of the Council and, in particular, the Czech Presidency.
Madam President, the Parliament and its rapporteur were compelled to reject a poor compromise, and they were right to do so.
Our delegation remained true to the position widely adopted in plenary, which called for the eventual elimination of all derogations to the legal working time.
But the truth is that Parliament was the only one wanting to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had decided beyond partisan divisions to put an end to this archaic practice known as the opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a genuine compromise text, which the Council of Ministers blatantly ignored, as did the Commission, for that matter.
The Council and the Commission have aligned themselves with the position of those who fiercely oppose any progress in workers' rights in Europe.
Mr. President of the Council, it is clear that you have achieved your objectives.
The Court of Justice requires you to consider all on-call time as working time, so you have not lost anything on that front.
The opt-out you want still exists in practice, so real estate has prevailed.
More than ever, the MPs elected next June will have to fight for the harmonization of social standards at the highest level.
Ah! But it's true!

Mr. President, this is certainly not on behalf of the LIBE committee, but rather likely on behalf of my group. I would like to take this brief moment to express my extraordinarily positive assessment of Mrs. Paganov's report.
I congratulate you, Madam, on your report.

I believe that in writing this report, you have developed an extraordinarily precise set of criteria for elements that should be prominently featured, Commissioner, in the Stockholm Programme, of which I am aware that the Commission is actively preparing.

Allow me to add to all that has been said, regarding the importance of judicial training, the significance of evaluation, and to emphasize two fundamental elements in mutual trust that underpin what could be, tomorrow, mutual recognition.
One, the independence of the judiciary.
At this time, within the Union, there are a number of countries where the independence of the judiciary from political power or from other powers is not established.
It is a scandal, and this scandal must end.
Secondly, procedural safeguards.

Until we are certain that, in a number of countries, individuals suspected or accused of committing certain types of offenses benefit from procedural guarantees similar to those in place in other nations, it will be challenging to gain widespread acceptance of the principle of mutual recognition.
This is a fundamental element, and I wanted to introduce it into this discussion.
Congratulations to Madame Pagat.
Madam President, we cannot remain silent on the situation in Madagascar, and we will not be alone in condemning it.
The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organization of La Francophonie, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the European Union represented by the Commission,

In the United States, a large number of countries, including my own and Norway, to mention European continent countries, have condemned the coup d'tat, because it is necessary to call a spade a spade, which took place in Madagascar.
We cannot remain silent and call for a return to constitutional legality.
We merely request a return to the status quo ante of the regions, with, if necessary, arbitration by the Malagasy people, through a consultation in the form of a presidential election or referendum.
It is incumbent upon the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
So, what we are asking for with this joint resolution is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly signal to those who have seized power in an entirely inappropriate manner,

in a democratic manner and in such a way, even if it takes the form of a coup d'tat, to restore the constitutional legality of Madagascar, which is one of the guarantors of the future development of this great island in the Indian Ocean.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, of course, I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and his responses, for the attention he continues to pay to all these disasters.
We worked closely together when President Barroso asked me to prepare a report, which he indeed cited, on the establishment of a European civil protection force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006.
When I reread it and see all the catastrophes that have occurred, I tell myself that it remains as relevant as ever.
Mrs. Zavala, obviously, it's not just Greece.
All countries are affected, and I would add that there are not only natural disasters, but also human-made disasters caused by humans.
I think of maritime disasters, the Erika and how many others, and industrial accidents like Chernobyl.
There are other natural disasters besides fires.
I am thinking about the tsunami.
We may one day fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean, as there was one in the early 20th century that completely destroyed the city of Messina.

Frankly, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the tools we are deploying are not equal to the task of addressing these disasters, which will multiply under the dual impact of climate change and transportation.
That is why I believe we need to be more ambitious.
I would like to thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all their teams, and the Directorate-General for ensuring the operation of the civil protection mechanism.
I believe we need to go further.
With those member countries that wish to do so, one can envision enhanced cooperation.
If we cannot be twenty-seven to form this civil protection force, let's start with twelve or fifteen.
And then you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I list the disasters, I can say that everyone is affected: the floods that hit Germany in 2002, and even major pandemics, as well as terrorism.
Here, Mr. Commissioner, is why I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose to the Member States that they go further.
Our Parliament, the Environment Committee, the Defense and Security Committee will support you in these proactive initiatives.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Parliament, this summer once again, the Mediterranean forest fell victim to flames in Marseille, in southern Corsica, but also in Italy, Spain, and on a larger scale, in Greece.
Over 400 hectares of forests and fields were reduced to ashes, causing significant material damage, irreversible harm to biodiversity, and dramatic losses of human life.
Appalled by this recurring toll year after year and cognizant of the multiplier effect of climate change on wildfires,
I call for a European awakening to better coordinate efforts and pool resources for firefighting.
I advocate for the realization of a comprehensive Euro-Mediterranean cooperation project to combat forest fires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I welcome the existing initiatives, including the European Forest Fire Information System, a pilot project.
I nonetheless call for a reform of the European Union's Solidarity Fund to make it an effective tool for responding to crises and to strengthen European resilience.
protection and the Euro Aid mechanism envisioned by Michel Barnier as early as 2006 to intervene within the territory of the twenty-seven member states and abroad.

I believe that one of the keys to the problem of wildfires lies in the sharing of knowledge and best practices in prevention, and I would like to highlight the pioneering role played by the forestry firefighters in my own department.
I can, of course, make this useful example available to Europe.
Mr. President, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I will be brief.
I believe there are two elements to this debate.
The pressing question is, how can we exit this crisis?
All measures that simultaneously provide aid to farmers or intervention measures are necessary and absolutely essential.
We must support them and even consider them to be more significant.
This is what we are proposing with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Secondly, there is a structurally posed question concerning the management of the milk market, and it is here that there is a divergence between us, Commissioner.
You propose to move towards contractualization.
I am telling you in advance, contracting between industry and agriculture, in the long run, with industries being competitive with each other, will lead to a Europe-wide competition.
We require public regulation to govern a market.
There is no other alternative.
This is where the debate must engage after this crisis.
I believe that, in this debate, we must respect all opinions and options, and I fear that we moved too quickly during the health check to resolve an issue such as quotas.

So far, I tell all those who have intervened, we have managed to maintain milk production in Europe, ensure a highly developed dairy industry, and at the same time, guarantee a price for consumers that was until now perfectly manageable.
Mr. President, just days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I truly feel that we can say that we are today more European than before.
I truly, fully, and serenely rejoice in it.
Unfortunately, unfortunately, we are still essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, as well as the goodwill of the Czech president.
A clear signal of accountability must be sent to those who hold in their hands the future of this crucial treaty for the Union, for our institutions, and for the 500 million Europeans we represent.
We can no longer be held hostage by a few individuals whose sole purpose is to undermine the broader European interest.

While it is legitimate for some to wish not to proceed further with European integration, and while it is legitimate to express these reservations, it is equally legitimate to allow those who wish to do so to progress.
In general, the processes for ratifying European treaties all too often resemble a saga or a victory achieved through legal maneuvering.
We are condemned to constantly having to push for the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms.
We will need to draw lessons from this chaotic ratification process and also, obviously, from this negotiation commitment with a view to organizing a second [event/round/attempt].

I would like a referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to make a people vote again after they have expressed themselves sovereignly, and as if it were normal for consent to a treaty to be a bargaining chip.
It concerns the institutional coherence and balance of the European adventure.
Ratifying a treaty is a minimal requirement of loyalty and cohesion once one has chosen for one's country to accede to the European Union.
We wanted to send a strong signal to citizens by ratifying the treaty in time for the European elections in June 2009.
What do you think the citizen today thinks of the Treaty of Lisbon and beyond our internal coherence and our legitimacy?
Mr. President, my intervention concerns the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the world's workers earn less than two dollars a day.
12.3 million people are still subjected to slavery, and over 200 million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of working poor is growing daily, and the International Labour Organization records 160 deaths each year due to a lack of prevention measures.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those who are deprived of employment and social rights, who work in undignified conditions.
of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide or victims of cancers or chronic diseases due to their working conditions.
It is time to break free from the religion of working more, the pursuit of profit, and short-term competition.
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the forefront of the Union's priorities in the coming ten years.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, a challenge, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To take up the gauntlet, Copenhagen must facilitate a comprehensive agreement, a single accord, as our Environment Committee chair, Joleen Anoui, emphasized earlier. An alliance of all nations, both industrialized and emerging, is necessary.

Today, through our debate and also the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we once again call on the European Union to maintain its leading role in this necessary policy of combating climate change.
Let us recall that it is imperative that we speak with one voice to maintain our credibility.
Yes, we must reach an agreement in Copenhagen to limit the increase in global average temperature to a level that does not exceed two degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must sign an agreement in Copenhagen to achieve collective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions of 30% by 2020 compared to 1990 levels.
But this will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to significantly reduce their emissions, but also for developing countries to contribute to the achievement of the goals.

Industrialized countries must therefore provide sufficient, lasting, and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must thus enable developing countries to move towards low-carbon models.
Allow me as well to explore two avenues that seem essential for our future.
Firstly, the global implementation of climate change mitigation financing through the taxation of financial transactions.
Subsequently, it seems necessary to me to implement a border tax adjustment for Europe that would apply to imports of products manufactured without any regard for environmental protection.

This involves the contractualization and reimbursement to Southern countries of the carbon tax thus collected at the borders of Europe, which would be used to finance investments in equipment necessary to combat global warming.
Mr. President, I would like to speak in line with my intervention from yesterday regarding the preparation for the Copenhagen summit, especially following the unsuccessful ECOFIN meeting yesterday.
I have addressed you regarding the responsibility we have, as an industrialized nation, to ensure that developing countries can follow in our footsteps in our efforts to combat climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same capabilities, as that would imply we all start from the same point and ultimately achieve nothing.
So, to convince our development partners to join us, we will obviously need to address the issue of the aid that should be granted to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.

At the upcoming European Council, the twenty-seven members must absolutely reach an agreement on how the European Union envisions aiding developing countries within the crucial context of climate change.
Yesterday, I said, the Council and the Council of Finance failed to reach a common position on this issue.
Yet, we know that this question is absolutely central.

The European Commission had already made proposals, and I absolutely wish that we take the lead to draw our partners towards the global solidarity necessary to overcome this problem of climate change.
Mr. President, I welcome the Swedish Presidency's efforts to reach an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the very strong wind of pessimism blowing over these future negotiations.
For my part, I believe it is not realistic to concede at this stage that the Copenhagen Summit was stillborn or that it will not lead to a conclusive agreement for all parties to ratify.
Let us not yield too quickly to pessimism.
I argue that at this stage, we should not scale back our ambitions, either in terms of goals or deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious, and binding global political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legal treaty as soon as possible.
It is truly too early to discuss the deadline for the COP 16 in December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into genuine political will.
We need to clarify our commitment in financial terms and in terms of aid to developing countries, particularly in terms of technology transfer.
At this point, a full and collective commitment from the European Union is indispensable.

I also note on paper the recent but exemplary momentum given, to speak, by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, Norway, in particular, which have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

While we can understand the flexibility sought by the United States, which is only beginning to consider the climate issue, we must still achieve quantified, binding, and ambitious short-, medium-, and long-term commitments from other major polluters, such as the United States and China.
In the absence of such measures, we are heading towards a climate, political, and moral disaster.
Madam President, we all know and have stated the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations, but while we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept one at any cost.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I strongly wish for the European Union to be able to say no and refuse to sign a watered-down deal.
The European populations we represent here expect an agreement, an agreement that will enable us to effectively combat all the climate disruptions we observe around us every day.
They will not be satisfied with mere announcements, unquantified statements of intent, or non-binding objectives that can be easily dismissed once the media spotlight has moved on.

In Copenhagen, states must commit. The European Union, the only continent to have seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, and the only one to foresee precise, binding, and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot shoulder the burden alone.

This is why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not wish to bear their share of the burden, we must draw all the consequences by introducing at our borders a tax that protects our industry from the competition of those who decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We Europeans demand a little more each day from our industries.
As evidence, I point to the climate package, which was signed under the French presidency.
As evidence, I point to national initiatives that, like the carbon tax praised earlier by Mr. Pargnoand I welcome thisare driving the establishment of ecological taxation.

A sector like transportation, which is among the major emitters of CO2, even though certain modes of transport, such as aviation, emit fewer greenhouse gases, is contributing increasingly to the fight against climate change.
Now, this is a sector that has been hit very hard by the fallout from the crisis.

If, as I hope, maritime and air transport are included in the Copenhagen negotiations, then let us ensure that what is asked of European industries is also demanded of those in other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, world public opinion will have its eyes firmly fixed on its leadership. Please finalize, if you will. Do not disappoint us, thank you.
Madam President, dear colleagues, the Copenhagen Summit is an historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must reach decisions that are even more binding than those made in Kyoto.
We, too, must call on our leaders to create an international organization, similar to the WTO, responsible for regulating climate change and environmental issues, and to establish a fund.
adaptation to climate change, in addition, of course, to public development aid, to create a maritime and air carbon tax, as should also be done for financial transactions.
We clearly see the pressing necessity for global regulation of the environment, much like that of financial markets and the Internet.
We have the opportunity to open this chapter of history through the lens of the environment.
Let us do this in the image of our highest human aspirations, otherwise we will appear as leaders with no grasp of the reality of things.

Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues, with less than two weeks until the Copenhagen conference, concerns are growing regarding the success of the climate change negotiations.
Some, indeed, are already saying that it will be a failure.
Major world powers still hesitate to show the full ambition that the climate emergency demands of us.

By adopting the resolution proposal tomorrow on the European Union's strategy ahead of the Copenhagen conference, we European parliamentarians must demonstrate that our resolve is first and foremost unwavering and that the conference must result in an agreement that is indeed precise but above all binding.
Furthermore, the binding nature of this agreement, once reached, must not be subject to challenge or dispute.

We cannot indefinitely postpone decision-making until tomorrow, or it will be too late. Hence the need for the creation of a world environmental organization, which today appears not only necessary but also urgent, as it will be called upon, under the auspices of the UN, to monitor the implementation of the commitments made in Copenhagen.
We must, from Copenhagen onwards, expect greater clarity and responsibility from the major world religions.

Mr. President, I would like to express my support for the joint initiative of the British Socialist government and the French government to repatriate Afghans in an illegal situation to their territories.
In fact, contrary to what some people have said, these individuals had their applications for political asylum rejected, and this bilateral initiative must now be extended at the European level.

The migratory pressure is a challenge that we must address collectively, and this is the essence of the pact on migration and asylum, voted on a few months ago, adopted a few months ago under the French presidency.
We must now go further by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights funded by Frontex.

The decision of the twenty-seven to request the Commission to conduct a study on this matter is a first step, and Commissioner, I hope the Commission will support this proposal, as combating illegal immigration is a public expectation and, in particular, a concern of the legally resident immigrant populations.
Mr. President, I would like to revisit a recent event: the Swiss vote on minarets.
Certainly, this vote took place in a state not belonging to the European Union, but it is evident that it concerns a matter that is not unfamiliar to us.
I would like to revisit this event as I also see it as a pretext to discuss secularism, and one cannot speak enough about secularism in this chamber.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularism underpins the organization of our society, and I would like to state some simple points here.
Firstly, the principle contrary to secularism is not religiosity, nor is it spirituality.
The principle contrary to secularism is religious communalism, which dictates rules and laws superior to civil laws, the communalism that confines individuals within subsocietal groups.
Our Union, by its history, is multicultural and multi-ethnic.
It is, and it will be increasingly so, and only secularism can enable individuals
Mr. President, the CESAR program, which aims to modernize air traffic management in Europe, is a major project.

How will the Commission prepare the next phase of the redeployment of these funds, particularly the financing of this essential program for the environment, as well as for our scientific and technical influence?
Is the Commission going to follow the recommendations of the report submitted in 2007, which stated that a high-level, qualified individual should oversee the political follow-up of this program?

Indeed, it will require overcoming numerous legal, psychological, and technical obstacles by unifying national airspace and bringing together air traffic controllers from various countries to work collaboratively.
If Europe was incapable of unifying its skies, how could it be capable of building a strong political entity?
Mr. President, Madam Minister, dear colleagues, the importance of the issue of climate change is no longer in doubt.

These impacts, in the short, medium, or long term, are undeniable, even if today the results of the GESE in a certain national newspaper make the front page and certainly strengthen the positions of the skeptics.
The Copenhagen Summit presented itself to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to bear witness, take action, and rectify the effects of the process that is climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this platform, not only because of the bold legislation we have in place to limit the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe stands as a union of countries that can truly make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a bitter taste, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has reached an agreement on the issue of limiting temperature rise to two degrees, even for a country as reluctant as China.
Brazil has just enacted a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly 39% by 2020, in line with its commitments.
Many others have also demonstrated great ambition regarding greenhouse gas emission reduction targets.
So I think of Japan and Norway.
Moreover, it is also important to highlight this very positive point, which was the consensus reached regarding the urgency of a mechanism to reduce emissions from deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text has been achieved on the implementation of the IRED Plus mechanism to reduce deforestation and thereby enable natural CO2 storage.
Far from a binding agreement but clearly in line with a political accord, the outcome of Copenhagen must lead us to question the reasons for such disappointment.
I attended the Copenhagen conference, like many of my colleagues, with a determination to participate, to help, and to witness an negotiating Europe, a leading Europe, in action.
My disappointment was great as Europe clearly did not receive the place it deserved in the negotiations, all the more so when it comes to the European Parliament.
To assert itself, Europe must demonstrate greater strength on this issue.
The meeting of our environment ministers in Seville was inconclusive, with our leaders appearing uncertain and hesitant, and we remain divided on our goals.
I hope that Mrs. Heidegger, drawing on her proposals and commitments, and appearing before the Environment Committee, will be able to bring the European Union's ambitions up to date.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, to avoid caricatures, of which we have heard a few this morning, I would like to recall some objective facts about Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular increase in average per capita income, and now the vast majority of Tunisians fall within the criteria defining membership in the middle class.

Over 90% of Tunisians benefit from social coverage, and more than a quarter of Tunisia's budget is dedicated to education, such that the country is among the first to have achieved the millennium goals in primary education.
Finally, as Mr. Michel reminded us earlier, women's rights are recognized and guaranteed.
At university, there are more female students than male students. Forty percent of professors are women, and a quarter of members of parliament, local elected officials, or journalists are women.
Many countries could envy such results.
Mr. President, the acts of fanatical criminals who killed Egyptian Christians cannot be attributed to an entire people and its government.
It would be unjust to hold Egypt and Egyptians responsible for this abominable massacre, the perpetrators of which are about to be judged.
Let us not confuse the acts of a criminal with the policy of a country, nor equate fanatics with an entire population. Finally, in claiming to interpose ourselves,
Between the Coptic Christians of Egypt and their Muslim compatriots, we are providing arguments to extremists who seek to portray Eastern Christians as agents of the West.
I heard you, excuse me, Madam President, Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, what is happening in Greece, Portugal, tomorrow in Spain or Ireland is scandalous.

These same Anglo-Saxon agencies, which complacently rated the rogue issuers and traders of toxic assets and saw nothing coming, are now of the utmost severity towards the states that came to the aid of a financial sector that did not deserve it.

The crisis caused by the irresponsibility of markets and banks, and this massive aid, are directly responsible for the worsening of deficits and public debt that these same markets now claim to sanction.

of the American state and two hedge funds of the same nationality that seek to profit from both the exorbitant interest rates imposed on Greece and the CDS market, these state loan insurances that are themselves subject to independent speculation.

Mr. President, today there remains less than 15% of the original stock of red tone.
Faced with such figures, the solution seems obvious.
Nevertheless, we must not forget the jobs affected by the decision that occupies us today.
It is important to recall that CITES does not aim to prohibit fishing, but rather to regulate the international trade of this fish, specifically the 80% exported to Japan.

By conserving tuna, we are indeed protecting a species that is dangerously sought after, but we are also encouraging the continuation of a more balanced and sustainable fishing activity, a fishery destined for our domestic market and one that supports jobs.

Mr. President, I am in favor of the idea of a red list inscription for tuna in Annex 1 of CITES, and although I believe this decision will be positive, I seek the Commission's support to enable a comprehensive restructuring of the fishing sector.
My question therefore concerns the modalities of this support.
France is requesting an eighteen-month reprieve, accompanied by financial measures for sailors and shipowners affected by a trade ban.
What is the Commission's vision on this subject?
Moreover, my concern, like many of my colleagues, revolves around equity.
How can we ensure that ships flying the flag of countries such as Tunisia, Libya, or others will enforce the ban on international trade with a rigor comparable to our own?
What will the new control measures and sanctions be?

The sustainability policy of our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the adjustments necessary to implement these measures.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, as the rapporteur has stated, this directive proposal indeed follows a vote by the Parliament, a point you also emphasized, Mr. Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks backfiring on those we intend to support.
In seeking to reduce the burdens on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust indispensable to their management and the dynamism of their activities.
Firstly, I believe it is necessary to be clear about the thresholds and what is meant by micro-entities.
These are small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with more than ten employees and an annual turnover in excess of one million euros.
Regardless of the member states, they represent an overwhelming majority of businesses.
Indeed, they may be local and have little presence in the community market, but it remains that the necessity to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them and that
Accounting rules will confront them every time they want to deal with a banking institution, partners, or sometimes negotiate with tax, economic, and social institutions.
At that point, accounting rules will be imposed on them, and they may have to pay more than for regular accounting in order to meet criteria that they may not necessarily control.
I do not see any progress in imposing the accounting obligation outside of any common framework for the European Union.
This is not merely a competition issue; it is fundamentally a matter of economic integration, Community law, and equal treatment for all businesses within the European Union.
In other words, clearly, simplifying accounting requirements for SMEs is a necessity.
