Three initiatives are moving in this direction, whether it's the proposal we are discussing today or the international framework IF.
I prefer that it be the revision of the Fourth and Seventh Accounting Directives for which the European Commission should soon make proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us by 2010, it seems they are being extended, but I do not believe that this deadline extension is sufficient reason for this.
to rush and do a half-hearted job, because these three proposals, while sharing the same objective, may not have the same structure and it seems to me, Commissioner, that it would be better,

It is clearer for companies to provide them with a single, comprehensive solution that will enable them to reconcile the goal of simplifying obligations desired by all and the reality of the lives of small businesses that need it.
The current issue is that the European Commission is delaying the proposal to revise this directive, which is hindering our discussions.

I therefore call on the European Commission to expedite the dialogue on the issue of exemption, which today divides both European institutions and economic circles, and to conduct an impact assessment.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin Chartier and others have pointed out, on February 27th and 28th, the violent storm Xintia struck several regions of France, causing 53 fatalities and immense material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity, causing devastating floods along the French coast.
After Madeira, Europe is once again affected.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have been declared in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes, and Pays de la Loire.
In the face of these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not just through words and a resolution, but above all through financial assistance that we can support the victims of these disasters.

I therefore call on, and my colleague Christophe Bcuy joins me in this request, the European Commission to unlock the EU Solidarity Fund swiftly to assist the affected regions in dealing with the damage.
This catastrophe demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are increasing and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands of the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I would also like to congratulate our rapporteur, Jrg Leichtfried, on his text and his cooperative spirit in this matter. I particularly support his proposals on the financing of air safety, as we are talking here about air safety and not air security.

For many years, our Commission has been fighting to have the principle accepted that the strictest security measures should be borne by the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security does not only concern travelers, but all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore unjustified for air passengers alone to bear the burden of financing security measures in airports and on board aircraft.
And all the more so given that, in transport modes such as rail and maritime, states fund security measures, in whole or in part, depending on the case.
I therefore believe that we must stand firm against the Council and defend Amendment 32 of the report adopted by our Transport Committee to the very end.
I had another point to briefly address.

While I support the progress on non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, identical European system for safety fees.
While enforcing adherence to common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to retain their current system of fee collection.

Thus, in states such as Spain, Italy, or France, royalties are voted on by Parliament, and in this case, it must be the appeals authority against laws that serves as the independent supervisory authority.
And this is the purpose of Amendment 40, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the report I am presenting to Parliament attempts to explain that, in the fight against climate change, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature reminds us this week that volcanoes, in particular, can have a significant impact on human activities and the climate.
This requires, nonetheless, that men and Europe in particular take responsibility to combat what is known as climate change.
My report aims to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to reduce its carbon emissions, decrease its consumption of fossil energy, and, above all, on the other hand,
Moncotte has been very actively involved in carbon sequestration to combat global emissions by reducing carbon releases and increasing the amount of carbon captured and stored.
This report aims to demonstrate that in agriculture, we should move away from a compartmentalized approach, if you will, which involves opening a new directive every time a problem arises.
on soils, on water, on pesticides, who knows what else, and trying to tackle the agricultural issue with the ambition to address it comprehensively, systematically.
In this approach, we need to identify ways to ensure that agriculture, as I mentioned earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also actively contributes to carbon sequestration.

It is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and especially what is close to my heart, also linked to the soil, to this capacity that European soils have to sequester organic carbon.

I believe that this approach, which I am introducing in this report and which I hope will be adopted during the vote in the plenary session in Brussels, will enable European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability and ensure a...

ecological transition in this agriculture, which would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other forms of agriculture, ensuring that it can be economically efficient, ecologically sound, and I believe also, from that point onwards, socially beneficial.

This report addresses a specific issue: the fight against climate change and agriculture. However, it aims, I hope, to open up other perspectives to feed, in particular, the debate on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I address the Commission, I will address, and I have often done so, the agricultural committees, I will also address the various ministers when the opportunity arises.
I believe we need to take a turn.
It is essential that this 2013 CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) be ambitious.
It is essential that it be based on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because agricultural Europe must ensure both food security and commit to sustainability.
In any case, this is what I propose in this report, and I hope that the Parliament, by a large majority, will follow me on this.

Mr. President, I would like to emphasize first and foremost that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments by closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over any other consideration, and under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines demanding the immediate and full reopening of airspace based on one or two test flights is, at the very least, indecent.

I believe it was Mr. Henain who earlier spoke about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with regard to trains, and I will take this opportunity to express my regret over the paralysis of air travel.
has been accentuated in certain countries, such as France, by the disruption of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
Returning to our subject, I would like to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airline companies affected by the ongoing disruptions.
And it is a decision that makes sense in a context already marked by crisis, but this aid must be exceptional in nature.

In this regard, I hope that among the criteria considered for their award will be the exemplary nature demonstrated by companies in the compensation provided to their clients who were victims of flight cancellations.
Indeed, it is unacceptable for certain companies to abuse the force majeure clause to evade their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation 261/2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and, if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not, moreover, bear the financial cost.
Moreover, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
And this, too, is not normal.

Companies, such as travel agencies, have insurance policies that cover them in exceptional circumstances, like the situation we have been experiencing for the past few days, and it is therefore essential to ensure that travelers are properly compensated for the flights that have been canceled.
Mr. President, mayhem, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophe, disasterthe press is not lacking for words to describe the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not linger on what has already been mentioned, particularly when one laments the colossal, one might say abyssal, financial impact, both direct and indirect, of this crisis.

While I welcome the possibility of considering the provision of exceptional public aid to the aviation sector, which has already been heavily supported since 11 September 2001, I remain perplexed by the European management of these events.

Given that 750 European passengers were injured, many of whom remain stranded across the globe. Given that economic losses are exponential with each passing day, how can it be explained that it took so long...

It is not one, two, three, or four, but five days that the European transport ministers take to meet via teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the establishment of differentiated traffic zones.
Secondly, no one disputes the necessity of applying the precautionary principle as an absolute priority, but today, as traffic is gradually being reauthorized in certain areas,

secure, with unchanged weather conditions, and given that the volcano remains active, one is entitled to wonder what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided earlier, more quickly.

Thirdly, an adaptive action plan has been developed; the evolution according to weather conditions and volcanic activity can change from hour to hour. This plan will continue to conduct updated assessments of the safety of the corridors.
Must these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this situation persists, worsens, or recurswhich is likelythe established management model should provide for greater coordination among member states and special operational procedures based on real data.

coordination of other transport means, under exceptional circumstances, while also taking into account the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of tens of thousands of stranded passengers, who also have the right to information and support.
So far, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken.
Madam President, I in turn, after other speakers, wished to express my thanks to our colleague Mndez de Vigo, who has done remarkable work under sometimes passionate and always exciting conditions.
Debates within the professional affairs committee lasted a long time, living up to the stakes and reflecting the intensity of interest that the countries concerned clearly have.
The European Parliament, whose major subject of concern, quite legitimately, is primarily related to the composition of our assembly and the procedures for appointing its members.
Once again, the rapporteur has successfully gathered sometimes differing opinions and contributions, and has synthesized, I would say, in an extremely balanced text, the various views and opinions.
I wanted to thank him for it.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both the one concerning the convening of the IGC and the one regarding transitional measures for the composition of our assembly, are characterized by realism, pragmatism, and effectiveness.
This, I believe, is what citizens, globally, and on other topics as well, expect from Europe.
Mr. President, Mr. Dalli, Mr. Commissioner, it is with great conviction that this draft report, as presented a moment ago by Mr. Peterle, echoes the Commission's guidelines.
This is the directive of the European Commission's communication and is also inspired by the European Parliament resolution of 10 April 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to endorse the objectives of the European partnership envisioned by the European Commission to more effectively combat cancer, whether it be the importance of prevention, early detection, the development of a new cancer prevention model, and above all, the reduction of inequalities among Member States.
I share the concerns and worries expressed within the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I would like to acknowledge the work done by Mr Peterle, rapporteur, in drafting this report and the compromise proposals put forward to accommodate the various amendments.

As a shadow rapporteur for the Socialist and Democrat Group, I have sought, among other things, to emphasize the following issues: firstly, the increase in annual cancer deaths caused by exposure to carcinogens in the workplace, but also the importance of improved access

information on medications for cancer patients, as well as the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular updating of substances of very high concern that include carcinogenic substances, and support for initiatives to prevent the importation of goods.

containing chemical substances that are carcinogenic and to strengthen the control of chemical substances within the European Union, and finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that can include people suffering from chronic diseases or cancer.
These are the questions we wished to raise while supporting this draft report.
Madam President, the oil rig leak in the Gulf of Mexico is an outright ecological and economic catastrophe.
It would appear that irregularities have been identified in the granting, by the United States Department of the Interior, of forestry permits.
This would be an unforgivable negligence with incalculable consequences, which do not only concern the United States of America.

When we consider that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by nations worldwide, if these permits are issued with the same lack of caution, it would pose serious problems for the entire globe.
elected representatives from the European Union's outermost regions and the OCTs composed entirely or almost entirely of islands, approximately 130 in number.
In total, spread across the three continents, I must express here my profound concern for our islands regarding offshore oil exploration projects.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, as a role model, rigorously re-examines its security and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
In addition, accidental or operational offshore oil spills, not necessarily originating from Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tonnes each year.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives to ensure that offshore platforms now fall under the purview of an undisputed international scientific authority, which should be established in the form of an international body?
After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would do well to initiate genuine global governance for the exploration, protection, and exploitation of deep-sea resources.
The continuity of the Barcelona process, the Union for the Mediterranean, is an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the eastern and southern Mediterranean basin.
As highlighted in the excellent report by Vincent Peillon, we cannot overlook either the potential of this region or the perils it entails.
Yet, with the lucidity to acknowledge this since the bombing of Gaza and the continuing colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
The political aspect is blocked.
We are not even certain that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will take place.
I would not be surprised if we learn, in the coming hours or days, that it has been adjourned, sine die.
We must not give up, but the European Union must take greater responsibility in the search for a political solution.
We cannot allow the United States to have a monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, by merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean region are crucial to our security and growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best tool at our disposal.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this is an extremely important matter regarding consumer protection.

A recent survey shows that the situation regarding food security has deteriorated over the past ten years in the eyes of Europeans, and one in three consumers remains skeptical about the quality of products.
Updating, simplifying, and clarifying food labeling in the European Union is therefore an obligation for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color-coding, we are in favor of this color system provided it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as percentages.
Then, I am opposed to mandatory nutritional labeling for wines and spirits.
We advocate for the development of a regulation specific to wines and spirits within the next three years, rather than the five years proposed by the European Commission.
This is what I wished to point out, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Mr. President, Madam High Representative, this attack on civilian vessels by Israeli commandos clearly demands an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credit can we give to a commission that is both judge and party?
This attack took place in international waters, and thus concerns the international community, particularly the European countries bordering the Mediterranean.
Europe should make its voice heard more strongly and become more actively involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making significant financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is largely absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary goodwill we demonstrate is not enough.
We must also express political will and take the necessary steps to make our voices heard.
The brutal murder of the MV Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army has sparked emotions and condemnations.
I would like to express my outrage at the nine victims of the civilian assault, condemning this interception in international waters as a violation of international law.
In doing so, the government of Israel penalizes its own people, for ultimately, we see that with the strengthening of extremes, the ultimate goal of security in the region moves further away.
Yes, now more than ever, the government of Israel must abandon the policy of force.

I would like to point out, however, that the extensive media coverage surrounding the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation appears indispensable to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
And I hope that the government of Israel will agree to include substantial international participation in this investigation to finally find the paths to justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the partnership for modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it were to achieve nothing else, would at least have the merit of underscoring the extent to which Russia is an indispensable geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive remarks on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the demands of the Union are always prioritized, the interests or positions of its partner are systematically undervalued or disregarded, whether in the field of energy or in how it may analyze the Eastern Partnership and the Atlanticist aspirations of its closest neighbors.

I also note that the firmness demonstrated by most member states and the European Union in their speeches, the virulence of their condemnations, and the violations of human rights, seem to be reserved solely for Russia.

The rhetoric is more cautious, the diplomacy more filtered, as if it were about China, for example, these systematic violations of the rule of law, if only regarding the labor conditions in this global factory, in light of minimal European social standards, while our French or European workers are unemployed.

Let me remind you of Adagusta's adage, Father Augusta, to the summits by the narrow paths, for this is how I view the efforts of today's Russia, freed from the criminal Marxist poison that, for so many decades, bled and confined this country.
The current Russian Confederation has managed to lift the spirits of an entire nation despite the significant difficulties and challenges that remain to be overcome.

So, a little humility, Gentlemen Europhiles, especially when the super European state, for its part, fails to achieve any of its fine objectives despite increasingly costly means and the progressive domination of the states of Western, Central, and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but recall that this Assembly showed more leniency towards the more communist Soviet Union than it did towards Russia.

It is often the same individuals who, yesterday, advocated for the unilateral disarmament of the West and participation in Mr. Gorbachev's common house, who today express the most virtuous indignation and the greatest modesty towards the Russia-Union partnership.

On this matter, I must inform you, in case you are not already aware, of new historical facts that are emerging due to the gradual translation of Soviet secret archives that a courageous Mr. Pavel Stroilov managed to obtain. These archives have already revealed and will continue to unveil much information.

It is an unpleasant surprise for the champion of monolithic thinking regarding the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was indeed, Mr. Gorbachev, and the deception of today's Eurocentric powers, who then enthusiastically sought to make certain Soviet projects possible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for the European states, and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.

This country is far closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests, and shared risks than are certain states that you are nonetheless preparing to admit to the European Union.
Mr. President of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
In the face of the crisis, an obvious fact, no, an inevitable necessity, that of innovating, of being creative.

In this regard, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step which I hope will ultimately be a giant leap towards genuine economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, mere coordination of economic policies will remain inadequate.
Could we achieve a genuine budgetary federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves would have decided it?
Let us return to the Council's decisions, which nonetheless please me.
Strengthening the preventive aspect of the Stability and Growth Pact is a very positive step, but there can be no true budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who fail to comply.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified, which is a regret.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, with regard to the decided orientations, such as the famous competitiveness assessment dashboard, because that is indeed what it is about: regaining competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
Let us also welcome the proposal to introduce a bank tax, the acceptance of a financial transactions tax, and the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, all these decisions and orientations seemed, a few months ago, or even a few weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory, or even truly hypothetical.
You are correct, it is true, it is a profound cultural shift on the scale of European incremental policy.
However, that said, it is now mandatory for states to implement these guidelines very concretely by October.

It now depends on the Council whether the step taken will be a historic giant leap or merely a pious hope, which we will all bitterly regret, and in particular, a majority of citizens, who will have to endure its consequences in their daily lives.

Mr. President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on the Gallo report, and clearly, the Parliament, all groups, still need to discuss it further because there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we were requesting to postpone the debate and vote on the Gallo report, that is, until September, September 2nd, when it will need to be addressed at the Conference of Presidents.
So, it's a very simple thing.
Given that the fruit is not ripe, let's give it the summer to mature and discuss it in September.

Madam President, I must admit that I struggle to follow my colleagues who are so keen to flex their muscles and claim the monopoly of our legitimacy in relation to the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisory.
But when the members of this house, through hard work and conviction, assert a well-argued position, when
We are advocating for what resembles a European common interest against rigid states; the situation changes completely.
In this debate on European supervision, the Parliament has played that role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, for which I serve as my group's shadow rapporteur, I advocated, like the rapporteur, Ms. Goulard, for an ambitious approach.
I have advocated for mechanisms that ensure a certain efficiency, and I have emphasized the preeminence of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is indeed the only Community institution in this group and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I choose to withhold the names of all the institutions and those great figures who suddenly vanished during the storm.
We can consider ourselves fortunate to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow's macroprudential supervision supported by a strong community institution, while microprudential supervision will inevitably remain fragmented.
Having become concerned, the European Systemic Risk Board must get to work as soon as possible.
The future will reveal whether adjustments are necessary, but it is crucial to start from a sound foundation, as systemic risks impact the entire European and global banking sector.
Mr. President, the final agreement reached on the overhaul of the directives relating to industrial emissions is more than acceptable, and I commend the compromise work that has been done.
This final package incorporates the key tax measures that I advocated for, along with several of my colleagues on the environment committee, aiming to make this text a bold yet realistic legislation.
Firstly, maintaining a degree of flexibility for businesses and competent authorities in granting exemptions.
Next, I would like to acknowledge the new version of the ESN, which has been so controversial and now, limited to certain sectors, seems much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better alignment with the ETS Directive and permanently removes the somewhat irrelevant idea of creating a SO2 and NOX quota market from the text of the new directive.
A few caveats to bear in mind, however, and more particularly the provisions relating to the ground.
The SOL directive still being pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by those Member States with their own specific legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached following the trilogues.

Enormous efforts have been made from all sides to avoid sending this text to conciliation, a text which, I must remind you, is of crucial importance for both industry and European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings new information revealing the full scale of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the offshore platform rupture.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind are happening elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today, and has been for a long time, in Nigeria.

That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter rules regarding platform management, not just European rules but also international regulations.
As far as the European Union is concerned, I believe it is necessary for it to proactively equip itself with tools to combat this disaster, and I think it is evident.
I also believe that all of this, as Mrs Damanaki said, argues for a firm and resolute choice in favour of clean and renewable energies.
The European Union should lead by example in this regard.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur while the European Union is set to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500 tonnes of beef.
A new opening of our market would be to the detriment of European disadvantaged area livestock farmers, without any guarantee of compliance with health and social standards.
We cannot accept this.
Europe purchases 38 million tonnes of soybeans and animal feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize over 19 million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, and Bunch.
Between 2001 and 2004, soy destroyed more than 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
It was one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the loss of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the reconquest of autonomy in plant proteins for livestock feed.
Environmentally-friendly agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be undermined by this draft bilateral agreement.
Once again, the European Commission is sacrificing its agriculture and farmers to obtain uncertain concessions for service sector businesses.
These concessions will not benefit the peasant families of Mercosur, but rather the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To convince oneself of this, one need only read the report by the Tyson Group, an American company and a major player in the international meat market.
which announces having invested in Brazil to, I quote and this is from its report, use the country as an export platform for Europe.
Other companies, like Doo Inc., had already anticipated this move by acquiring the Brazilian group Frango Soul in 1998.
Many poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, bore the brunt of this operation.
Europe, without intending to continue its policy of offshoring, is intensifying its attacks.
against the peasants, we must stop
Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the potential impact on European agriculture that the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur could have.
My group and I share these concerns.

Indeed, it is to be feared, and as a representative of an ultra-peripheral region, I have experience with the banana agreements. Therefore, it is to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur could deal a severe blow to many European agricultural sectors.
This is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.

There is also a concern that this agreement may further shift, perhaps too much, the agriculture of Mercosur towards a productivist model, to the detriment of smallholdings that exist in these countries.
A balance must therefore be struck so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers rooted essentially in the dogma of mercantilism.
Mr. President, I would like to simply tell you that perhaps we did not manage our agenda well today after all.
If we allow free trade agreements to bring products into Europe that do not meet our social or environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be pointless.
In very clear terms, we cannot remain in a state of hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental, health traceability, and safety constraints.
to our farmers, on the grounds that consumers must be protected, while at the same time allowing products to enter our continent freely without adhering to these standards.
The question that lies at the heart of the negotiation with Mercosur is indeed this one.

The way in which things have been initiated, despite what we are told about the Parliament being fully informed and the process being conducted with the utmost transparency and clarity, does not lead us to form a positive assessment of a negotiation that is taking place while, in parallel, negotiations at the WTO continue.
In the name of consistency, consumer protection, and the defense of our farmers, I do not believe we should continue down this path.

Madam President, I would also like to acknowledge the work done by the rapporteur, Jos Bov, and commend the Commissioner. I also welcome the contribution of Mr De, who spoke before me, regarding the objectives of this report.
I believe it is crucial for us to bear in mind that, in the debate we are having, we need to address an issue related to price volatility in agriculture, and particularly to the fact that when prices
When prices rise at the production level, these increases are very quickly reflected in distribution, but when prices fall at the production level, there is no corresponding decrease for consumers.
There is indeed an issue with the organization of the sector, and there is also a problem with the distribution of what is known as value added within the sector.

I believe that Jos Bov's report provides, on several points, perspectives that should be highlighted, and here I am really addressing the Commission to try to break out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the supply chain and the power dynamics within it.
What proposals do we have to ensure that producers, when united and organized, have more influence within the sector to negotiate?
This is the question you raised, Commissioner, regarding interprofessional organizations, but it also concerns the contractual framework that will be established.
I argue, and it is within the report that this contractual basis has a European framework.
We cannot leave it to each country to solve this problem.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
This is a proposal, an inseparable lead for me.
Secondly, of course, the issue of price transparency.
And on this point, I am in favor of establishing this observatory, which is absolutely necessary to enable us to inform consumers about price developments.

Here is my translation:

Well then, I support the proposals that have been made, and I hope, as Mr. Desch said, that there will be a majority in favor.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, today I would like to welcome this debate, which once again highlights the need for the Union to recognize and valorize its regional diversity.
In these years of negotiating the new framework programs for 2014, it seems important to me to emphasize the adjustments that specific regions must benefit from.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the forefront of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, insular, or sparsely populated territories requires more than a set of derogatory measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We need to establish the instruments that can synergistically coexist all areas of community action in order to enhance their added value.
Furthermore, as a representative of the outermost regions, I eagerly await the new Union strategy for the UPRs that the Commission services have promised us for early 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I align myself with my colleague's position on the absence of the Council from this Parliament meeting.
I find this a bit cavalier on the Council's part, I also want to say.
As the upcoming summit on October 6th approaches, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely strive to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at this very time, we were already busy in this very hemicycle, urging Europe to do everything in its power to reach an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We have seen that the result did not meet our expectations and ambitions.
So, the concerns, a year later, are the same, if not even more acute.

In order to constrain or convince our partners today, we must demonstrate that our resolve is absolutely intact, showing, for instance, that we are providing the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the Global South.
For this, the implementation of innovative financing mechanisms, and I heard yesterday President Sarkozy's speech at the UN, is becoming a necessary evidence.
So, for instance, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be excluded.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not going far enough in their climate commitments, much more than a threat in the end, and a way to protect our jobs and businesses, especially to better address the post-crisis period.

Madam President, for me, the need to revalue family leave is not in question. Increasing the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward, a benefit, and we should not be entirely demagogic in comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits that are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially twofold: the economic context, which is true, but insufficient to continue neglecting millions of families for decades; and the legal shortcomings of the report, as the text contains several types of family leave whose legal bases are not reconcilable.
Let's take the adoption leave, which is included in the text on the same footing as maternity and paternity leave.
Personally, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, I appreciate the willingness to grant rights equivalent to those of biological mothers.
In fact, I am the small additional package mentioned by Mrs Morin, to be added to the Estrela report.

Mr. President, if the objective is indeed to strengthen the health and rights of women, all women in the labor market, adoptive mothers who have become mothers just like the others are entitled to the same rights and the same workplace protections.
They are mothers like any others, in every respect, whether they adopt a child under or over twelve months of age. Moreover, there is no discrimination, please note, as indicated in the text.
As for adoption, I regret that the text was not more thoroughly explored.
It was not even informed by the Ramboll impact study.
All of this is not well developed, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these reservations, I will support Mrs. Estrela's report because, beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better fulfill their parental responsibilities in a society that

He is increasingly absent in the education of his youth, but moreover, because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council, but in Parliament. If we, the directly elected representatives, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, I would like to intervene and not revisit the debate as it has unfolded thus far.
We discussed a 2011 budget within the constraints we know, namely those of a deep crisis that Europe is going through, with national public deficits, which can lead to two hypotheses.
Do these national public deficits constrain the European deficit, or do these deficits at the national level need to provide a new direction and a fresh impetus at the European scale?
That is the question.
I ask you, Commissioner, above all to try to think, when we discuss a budget revision, when we are about to start talking about budget perspectives for the period after 2013, not to
She cannot remain entirely immersed in the context of the crisis, unless she tells me and tells all European citizens that, definitively, Europe will remain in crisis for a long time.
Our entire problem is indeed managing the crisis and reducing our deficits and debt, but it is also about preparing for the post-crisis period.
This is where the budget question arises.

We will only be able to emerge from the crisis, and Joseph Daul immediately pointed this out, if the European budget, precisely because it is European, can provide us with the means to regain what is currently lacking in terms of growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

This is the crux of the matter, and it is in this context that we must discuss the budget, rather than constantly incorporating, as we all too often do, the issue of the crisis and the question of deficits. In this regard, the Council is excellent.

I have observed that at Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even preemptively announced a treaty reform without even discussing with Mr. Van Rompuy at all to penalize all states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

This is where we stand at the Council level today, as Parliament is only asking one thing, particularly of the Commission, which is to decide to drive the European project forward, and this happens through the budget.
You have noted a number of points on which we are in complete agreement.
There is a need for greater flexibility.
Obviously, we need to collectively find a way to have a much more flexible budget, because it is a matter of necessity; the reactivity of Europe is at stake.
It is also, of course, a matter of setting priorities and organizing the effectiveness of the European budget.
We will all agree on this, all agree, it is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear with each other, Mr. Commissioner, is that we need to have a timeline, to set joint objectives. It cannot remain just words, just commitments, just

These are texts that are, moreover, very interesting and with which I agree almost 100%. But now it is necessary to get down to specifics and, in particular, on an essential question that we keep circling around: own resources.

How can we ensure that clean resources are available tomorrow for Europe, not just for Europe, but for all European citizens, and how can we collectively regain the path to growth and a stronger future for Europe?
It is your turn, Commissioner.
Mr. President, I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation of the upcoming G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers regarding European economic governance, the need to strengthen European economic governance, to reinforce the Stability and Growth Pact, and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly mention two challenges facing our nations, and indeed the members of the G20, which must be addressed, in my view, at the upcoming G20 meetings.
the challenge of the currency war and that of the volatility of raw material prices.
I believe that on these two issues, which are genuine threats to global growth and cause significant imbalances on our planet, the European Union must take action.

The European Commission is able to organize itself, adopt common positions, and equip itself with the means to speak with one voice at upcoming G20 summits, including Seoul and those that follow, as well as more broadly on the global stage.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feio on the quality of the report and the ambitious proposal it contains.
So, this also demonstrates that the European Parliament is fully engaged in a debate that is crucial for Europe's future, and we can only applaud this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis served as a revealer of the dysfunctions undermining the economic governance of the European Union.
I note on this point Mr Feio's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
For this, I believe the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, particularly the sanctions.
This is essential if we want to achieve a sustainable improvement in the budgetary situation of states, which is not always popular.
It is restrictive, but we have no choice.

Mr. President, I believe that the report clearly highlights the issues surrounding the marine environment in terms of fisheries, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, research combined with climate change.
This is a considerable development potential that should be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, as the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its outermost regions provide it with the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
In light of such a finding, it is therefore the responsibility of the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world's leading naval power that does it, who will do it in its place?
But it must be acknowledged that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with 50 million euros that one can claim to occupy a position of leadership in global politics.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, as they are present in all oceans, it would have been possible to reduce them.
It was wise to give them a leading role in a grand ocean strategy, which, unfortunately, was not retained in the report, and I regret that, Mr. President.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
Moreover, 75 American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
They argue that ACTA, as a mere executive agreement, would be contrary to the U.S. Constitution.
As the European Parliament is set, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, it continues to raise significant concerns and is far from achieving unanimous support.
Among our fellow citizens, I believe it would be useful to obtain a very clear response from our American interlocutors on two points: Can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is ACTA, in their eyes, a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement already absent of China, India, and Brazil, which is not implemented by the United States, would significantly lose its credibility.
I thank you.

Mr. President, throughout this difficult birth of the directive on alternative funds, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle may sound like an obvious truth, but that truth has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory in nature.
I would like to thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr Gozes, who, after this particularly painful delivery for him, deserves a substantial maternity leave.
I would like to emphasize above all that the issue of the treatment of third countries must still be viewed in two ways, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks in large part to the European Parliament, all funds sold within the European Union will effectively be subject to comparable regulation.
One can then speak of a more or less level playing field.

It remains that, during the transitional period, non-European entities will benefit from the national placement regime, while funds and managers from the European Union will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.
The situation is different in markets located outside the European Union, where European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, unlike funds from third countries.
It would then be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world as they will be less flexible and more expensive.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was, to some extent, unavoidable.

As for depositaries, be aware that we will also make the requirements more stringent, particularly due to the new responsibilities that will burden them and which should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to express my opposition, but to point out that this new regulation is not trivial. Its implementation, which is necessary, will also present challenges that we must be aware of.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, especially in the early 21st century, patients require appropriate information to be fully engaged in their care journey, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in agreement with healthcare professionals, and to strictly adhere to the planned treatment.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposals for revising the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which we consider to be a nonsensical approach in terms of addressing the actual needs of patients.
This operation holds no interest for either citizens or member states.
It meant, on the contrary, additional bureaucracy, increased expenses, and putting patients at risk.
It is for these reasons that we initially submitted a proposal to reject these texts, thereby requesting the Commission to revise its approach.

This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schilter from the Greens group, enabled our rapporteur, Mr Feischner, whom I welcome, to undertake a significant revision of the Commission's proposals.

In parallel, we had tabled around sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients' access to independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the environmental committee has enabled a greater emphasis on patients' right to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.

In light of the compromise amendments secured, we have resolved to withdraw our proposal to reject the texts, as the substance of the text has progressed in a favorable direction over the past few months.
The draft report, as amended, has succeeded in counterbalancing the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to oppose the instrumentalization of healthcare professionals to distribute brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies to their patients, without any oversight from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial-scale information campaigns, particularly regarding vaccination.
Information cannot freely flow from pharmaceutical firms.

Experience shows that we must be very vigilant and, moreover, and in conclusion, what has happened with the mediator drugs demonstrates the extent to which we must be vigilant and ensure that this balance point, as we have sought it with this draft report,

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Minister, the Union and realism will be reflected, at least I hope so, in tomorrow's vote on our resolution for this sixteenth conference of the parties on climate change.

I hope that our commissioner in charge will be able to advance the pragmatic objectives that we must collectively achieve, while also upholding the non-negotiable conditions set by Europe that are associated with them.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness from our fellow citizens and industries.
It is the world that must fight climate change, not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is far too little protected will be essential.
Green technologies should benefit the greatest number, but we must not, for all that, sell short our present and future knowledge, even in this indispensable fight against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methods for calculating emissions, as well as the verification and publication of data, so that all emitting industries are subject to the same standard, seems to be a highly legitimate request rather than a negotiating tactic.
Finally, and this is more contentious, as my colleague mentioned earlier, the shortcomings of the current clean development mechanism system will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, to our regret, that the true negotiating power is not held by the European Parliament.

But the willingness of many European lawmakers, including myself, to work and contribute to a positive outcome of this conference should be encouraged, not overlooked, as we have felt in these closing hours.
If Europe aims to be strong within international dialogues, the same must be true for all these legislators.
Madam President, the European Union often presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
She is therefore desperate to see these agreements signed as soon as possible.
But the question that intrigues us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so beneficial to them.
Clearly, assessments diverge on the quality of these agreements, and as long as these differences in opinion persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of the ACP countries?
These individuals wish to discuss development strategy, whereas Europe often responds with market opening.
It is this listening that the ACP-European Union Joint Parliamentary Assembly imposes upon itself.
I believe that other European institutions should follow suit if we are to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Mr. President, Christians are undoubtedly one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, "legitimate targets," and the goal is their complete and utter departure from this region, a region that saw the birth of Christianity and where their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at the Baghdad cathedral are merely the culmination of a situation we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and trading partner of many countries in this region, must strongly express its indignation in light of the situation.
Any and all forms of discrimination are intolerable.
Democracy will only triumph in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
Dear colleagues, we are all confronted with the serious crisis currently prevailing in Cte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the decision of this country's Constitutional Council to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the independent electoral commission, is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the Joint Parliamentary Assembly European Union-ACP, the COAS, and soon certainly the European Parliament are calling for respect for the official proclamation.
the election results and the inauguration of the new President of the Republic, as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission, which, I remind you, is a body accredited by the United Nations.
All political groups in the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint statement, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for a halt to any escalation of tensions in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Cte d'Ivoire, something that must obviously be avoided at all costs.

Madam President, in turn, I would like to thank our four rapporteurs who have done remarkable work and have added significant value from the European Parliament to the text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizen initiative we are about to vote on enthusiastically in the EPP is a major advancement of the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us not be mistaken, this instrument can truly transform the European political landscape, provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness, I reiterate, responsibility and boldness.
It can help bring European citizens directly into the European political debate.
It can help to foster a European public opinion, that is, men and women who are citizens of Europe, debating together, taking positions together, and rallying around truly European issues.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our member states to swiftly adopt the implementing measures where necessary, and not disappoint our fellow citizens. This is about strengthening European democracy.
Mr. President, I in turn, like several of our colleagues, wished to address the issue of the persecution of Christians around the world, particularly the Christians of the East.
No one needs to be reminded of the horrible acts recently perpetrated.
I would like to solemnly reiterate that defending Christians in the East, as well as everywhere else in the world, advocating for religious freedom, and promoting religious diversity...
This belief is advocating for freedom, democracy, and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, universal values, as we are all convinced here.
It is truly time now, beyond indignation, emotion, and solemn condemnations, obviously, it is truly time now to move from words to action.
I therefore urge the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, as well as all our leaders, the Ministers of Foreign Affairs.
Implement precise measures, establish a clear and concrete plan of action to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Madam High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has significantly deteriorated.
Allowing a lawless zone to establish itself at Europe's gates is a danger we must firmly and promptly combat.
Extremist groups are proliferating and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
In my turn, I deplore the loss of life and the hostage-takings, and I am concerned for the European citizens on the ground.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking from the Sahel.
Now, drug, arms, or human traffickers are bypassing Morocco by transiting through Mauritania to the Canary Islands en route to the European Union.
It is, I believe, the responsibility of the European Union to act in order to help these states put an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake not only on our territory but also in its immediate neighborhood.
It is time for us to act, and I call on the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to assist in the return to security in the Sahel.
This is what was said, but I associate myself with the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been extended to the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
He represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedoms.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to state that the European Union, which, as has been mentioned, has been criticized for its lack of response, must firmly stand alongside the Tunisian and Egyptian people to help them successfully open their countries to reform and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support the Tunisian leaders in initiating a peaceful transition, preparing the organization of upcoming elections, to achieve freedom and enable the Tunisian people to attain the prosperity of development and social peace, an economy that will allow youth to find employment.

I will say in conclusion that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
She must implement a robust strategy towards these countries.

But beware, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of the people, and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have reminded us of this on numerous occasions.

At a time when Europe is questioning itself about a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and particularly rare earths, we cannot neglect the immense potential represented by the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the operation of collection chains, addressing the problem of leakage or illegal export of said materials, and increasing our collection targets must be at the core of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
Citizen empowerment is crucial if we are to implement effective legislation.
To achieve this, my dear Carl Heinz, the eco-contribution, among other systems, has proven to be one of the most relevant tools.
Electric and electronic equipment producers must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but we cannot absolve citizens of responsibility for the waste they generate.
Our citizens must be actors, not spectators, of European environmental policy.

Madam President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to begin by echoing the remark just made by Mrs. McGuinness regarding the essential link between the food issue and the agricultural question.
The issue that concerns us is the rise in food prices, and the consequences this may have for numerous populations around the world, including in Europe.
I would first like to try to share an observation.

The tendency towards increasing agricultural prices and agricultural raw materials prices is, for me, a long-term trend that will persist for three essential reasons: the world's demographic evolution and the resulting increase in demand, the rise in production costs, and the limited elasticity of supply in the agricultural sector.

Second point is the fact that, with climate change, we have entered a phase of climate variability that presents problems, whether it be drought or flooding. Thirdly, because the world is also developing.
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are rising.
The tension in agricultural markets and agricultural commodity markets is a significant and persistent trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility, and price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
It is on this very subject that we must also focus if we are to resolve the agricultural and food issues.

To achieve this, what the commissioner says is important; there are two key elements: yes, there needs to be transparency regarding stocks, but there also needs to be a public policy on stocks in Europe and stock management on a global scale, particularly at the level of the UN.

Second point, there needs to be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing to allow speculative volume to become completely disconnected from the physical quantities traded on the markets.
We cannot accept that, on the food issue, speculators come to speculate without considering the consequences this may have, as it concerns the food of the world and humanity. I conclude for
Because this leads to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy, and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global player in food and agriculture.

Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, on a global scale, with Europe as a key player, we reinvest in agriculture, as we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, as in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is soaring on global markets.
We are only 3 levels away from 2008's level.
The decline in production in certain traditional export zones due to climate change, the diversion of cereals for agrofuel production, and speculation.
The financial banks that inadvertently experienced upward effects are responsible for this situation, as shown in reports from the IMF, French authorities, and as also stated by the Commission.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely affecting the 1.2 billion people worldwide who live on less than $1 per day.
Since the month of October, an additional 44 million people have joined those living below the poverty line.
With two days until the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those approved in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the U.S. administration has required the limitation and transparency of financial funds' positions on agricultural commodity markets.
This is the first step in countering the speculators' appetites.
The impact is dramatic for European breeders as well.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are in bankruptcy.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per ton; today, it is trading at nearly 300 euros.
The rules of the game have thus changed completely.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals; it would be well advised today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must confront the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of cereal stocks in producing countries to make them available to breeders at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, indexing the prices of meat paid to breeders on the evolution of feed prices.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism to transfer a portion of the aids intended to support cereals to animal productions. Thank you.
Mr. President, are we prepared in Europe to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there is a however.
The 2009 influenza outbreak in Chania revealed that each Member State reacted on its own, with little coherence or solidarity.

As a shadow rapporteur on this file, I believe it was necessary to make these observations, but above all to go further, to be constructive and concrete for our citizens who, it must be said, and this is indeed what seems most regrettable, have likely lost a little confidence in public health messages.

The report by Mrs Rivasi, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into account these fundamental priorities, which include, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States and improved coordination with the...

European health institutions, a clarification of the roles of European structures for managing health risks, an assessment of the vaccination and communication strategies implemented in the Member States.
This is therefore a good report, I congratulate the rapporteur, although obviously it must not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our member states, which retain most of the competences in this area, and thus a true responsibility towards our citizens.
Mr. President, it is my turn to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination on March 2nd of the Pakistani Minister responsible for Christian minorities, Mr. Bati.
This terrorist assassination follows numerous others targeting courageous, tolerant Pakistanis, lovers of human rights, defenders of human rights and women's rights, I must say.

Once again, we urgently call on the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of those threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
I am thinking, of course, first and foremost, but not exclusively, of Ms. Sherry Rehmann.
I wished also, once again, to strongly urge all relevant institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations towards
I would like to prepare future cooperation agreements, including the cooperation agreement between the Union and Pakistan, with a clause upholding religious freedom and respect for human rights.
Mr. President, for the record, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.
The Irish public deficit, the cumulative budgetary balance of central, local, and especially social security administrations, was estimated at 32% of gross domestic product in 2010.

If the Irish government, which is struggling to refinance itself through the markets, wishes to access loans from the European Financial Stability Mechanism and Fund, it will have to meet social and fiscal reform obligations, even though these areas fall under subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a physician, I would say that in the case of fever, it is futile to blindly prescribe antipyretics without attempting to treat the underlying cause.
In the event of the allocation of these funds, it is incumbent upon that state to undertake a financial restructuring in order to address its excessive deficit and rectify its previous errors.
This austerity plan is expected to increase GDP by 10% over the next four years.

Just as a bank, without interfering in an individual's private life and management, would condition a personal loan on a guarantee of solvency, so too can the European Union lend to Ireland based on consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in his private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

By adhering to the principle of subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency requires a reduction in the legal minimum wage and an adjustment of pensions, without exempting itself from fiscal measures.
It is up to Ireland to decide whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not an open door to interference by the European Union in areas of subsidiarity, which could dangerously impose a European minimum wage level, but rather a protection of the stability of the eurozone through a process of mutual guarantee.

Of course, it is appropriate to assist Ireland, as well as other countries in distress, which also protects us, but not at any cost, especially not at the cost of seeing a state unable to repay its debts in the long term, thereby jeopardizing its own citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, and many of us have said so just now, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of European airspace.
And each one of us in this chamber has been directly affected.
Five million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded without a viable alternative transportation solution.
One year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still pending.

A first crisis exercise, as you mentioned, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash is indeed scheduled for April 13 and 14, under the coordination of Eurocontrol, the ICAO, and IATA. However, it is crucial that EASA take on a genuine leadership role for the coordination of safety measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse needs to be refined using more modern technological means.
These data, as seen last April, can however be contradictory and may lead each Member State to make decisions regarding the closure of their airspace, less driven by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the EASA is crucial in providing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond the information provided by the VACs, EASA must establish a mechanism for collecting available data by closely involving Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all relevant stakeholders will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission, together with the ESA, to rapidly present concrete proposals that will fully contribute to the implementation of the European Single Sky.
Madam President, dear colleagues, this text is important.
This is not a revolution; one cannot say that everything was wrong before and that everything is perfect now.
Nevertheless, it does present a number of significant advancements at this provisional stage of our work.

The main issues, in my opinion, concern better regulation of distance selling and, in particular, over the Internet, and this is Chapter 3 because it is necessary to strengthen consumer rights in this area.
E-commerce is highly beneficial; it expands consumer choice, enables them to secure the lowest prices, and also provides small and medium-sized enterprises and artisans with new market opportunities.

To make progress in this area, it was necessary to do so in a truly European way, that is, by focusing on a few specific points and establishing a complete harmonization of rights and responsibilities for all.

In very practical terms, it was necessary for an Italian customer buying on a Belgian website or a German website to know that, from now on, they will benefit from the same rights and the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its cooling-off period will be extended to fourteen days across the entire Union.
This means that he will immediately know the total amount he will have to pay, without fear of an unpleasant surprise afterward.
This means that, thanks to the double-click, he will correctly verify his order.
Obviously, all of this will disrupt certain habits.
In many states, there are nuances in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, while sometimes they are not even found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to adjust these habits somewhat in the service of the common and general interest.
Let's be clear, this text will need further improvement, and we will have to do so in the coming weeks, with the Council and the Commission.
I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already accomplished substantial work thanks to our rapporteur, Andreas Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the true fruit of this labor is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumer confidence in the European Union's internal market is very fragile.
It was necessary to have this political unanimity to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point 7, after the first paragraph, a first bullet point should ensure respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular the freedom of the person.
Freedom of speech and assembly, and the right to peaceful protest, as well as the right to hear and address the legitimate demands of protesters and to ensure their safety.

Madam President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, the open skies agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only a stage, a stage that places Europe before a dilemma.
The transport committee and the Commission themselves have emphasized this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European businesses, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits gained since 2008.

Allow me, then, to draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer, as pilots, of whom I am one, find themselves faced with a dilemma.
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency, seeking to harmonize licenses across the European territory, will do so to the detriment of the 90 general aviation pilots.
directly affected, some holding only a single American license, and to the detriment, which is significant, of businesses and jobs associated with this activity.
Mr. President, I would like to draw your attention to this project which has no security foundation.
There are 31 times fewer accidents among American license holders.

The objectives of the basic regulation text 216 provide for the recognition and equivalence of licenses, the benefits of which should not be delayed awaiting hypothetical agreements postponed until 2014.

Therefore, I suggest a very open-sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I occasionally come to Parliament, piloting the aircraft myself, to demonstrate that an American pilot's license is perfectly safe.
Madam President, at this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be led to repeat or to endorse some of the points that have already been made.
But I also wanted to say that, like several of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, that the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be resolved by any single Member State alone.
No member state should face the challenges ahead alone, which, once again, in my view, concern the entire European Union.
I am thus truly calling for the European Union's ability to organize itself and respond in a joint manner, in a spirit of solidarity.
I believe that the time has truly come now to lay the foundations for a genuine European policy on immigration and asylum.
Over a year ago, a European pact on asylum and migration was adopted.
The time has come now, I believe, to outline this in a very concrete manner.
