We have indeed, Madam Commissioner, we have heard a number of recommendations that she made.
I wanted to revisit this and strongly emphasize certain proposals.
Yes, at all costs, the resources of the Frontex agency must be strengthened.
Therefore, it is necessary to strengthen the human, material, and financial resources of the Frontex agency, enabling it to provide more robust support to the Hermes and Poseidon operations.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed, specifically for Member States that are facing, I would say, foremost, the heightened migratory flow we are experiencing today.
This will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, we need to forge closer cooperative relations with the states on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, to accompany them, of course, to assist them, and to identify appropriate tools.
The Commissioner, I believe she mentioned that she went to Tunisia to discuss them, was referring to mobility partnerships.
Yes, we must strengthen these instruments with a sense of responsibility, with a spirit of solidarity, but also with a clear and practical mindset.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, you are undoubtedly aware that the most intense discussions we have had here regarding your communication have centered on the role of public services, services of general interest, within the single market, and their legislative translation.
We have reached a compromise formulation that encourages you to go beyond your proposal 25, and we ask you to exceed a mere [literal: simple] statement.

communication that does not meet the expectations and needs of stakeholders, users, and all stakeholders in public services, and that also does not align with the objectives you have otherwise outlined.
The European Union must deliver a clear and unambiguous message regarding public services.
For this, we must create a positive legal framework, whether a regulation or a directive.
The Treaty of Lisbon provides us with the legal foundations.
It is up to you to translate them now into legislative proposals.
I believe that Parliament is ready to follow you down this path.
Mr. President, firstly, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their gigantic work on this discharge, and I also welcome the presence of the Council for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and it is not solely an economic issue.

I am speaking about this today in this chamber on the occasion of the debate on the 2009 discharge, because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the Committee on Budgetary Control as a windfall, a mere means of making savings.
The issue of Parliament's expenditures also interests me.
In this regard, I suggest holding the group weeks in Strasbourg instead of Brussels, as this would enable us to make better use of our Parliament seat in Strasbourg.

Since we aim to save costs, I suggest implementing further measures. For instance, we could eliminate the daily allowance for Friday among our colleagues and also remove the daily allowances for journalists.
Europe is sufficiently attractive that one should not feel compelled to offer a per diem to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond the scope of budgetary control, even though I welcome the important work of Ville, our rapporteur, on this discharge.
Finally, since we are discussing savings, I also hope to see the moralization and improvement of the system for compensating sponsored visitor groups.

I find it highly unethical and it reflects very poorly on our institution that the group leader is reimbursed in cash, on the day of the visit, with no accounting or oversight of the group's expenses.
Sometimes, the allocated amountI am informing youexceeds the actual expenditure.

It would be logical for groups to send an estimate in advance to the visits service, to receive a Parliament account for expenses, and for this to be paid into a bank account, with the balance paid on presentation of the invoices actually settled, subject to a clearly defined ceiling. Thank you.
Madam President, I am addressing the Commission, my colleagues, and I acknowledge the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; on the contrary, it is an area that has continually expanded in recent years and now comprises twenty-five states, three of which are non-members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it now covers, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this light that we must read the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration.
Mutual trust between the States parties to the Schengen Area is indeed the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air pockets, the entire system becomes defective.
It should therefore be possible for other States to address this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly regulated control of these borders.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly encouraged to better secure their external borders.

Furthermore, as presented by the Commission, these measures will fully respect the spirit of Schengen, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be taken at the European level rather than intergovernmental.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to the full range of long-term measures envisioned with a view to a common migration policy.
It is particularly essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide more solidarity, I conclude, in order to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation that the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years merely highlights a gap in the Schengen acquis.
Madam President, within a matter of weeks, migrants from countries bordering the Mediterranean have accounted for a significant percentage of France's annual immigration.
This achievement is not static but must, on the contrary, evolve.
I hope that these proposals will be adopted swiftly, to ensure as soon as possible better management of our Schengen area and thereby secure our common external borders. I thank you.
Mr. President, the European Union has finally imposed sanctions on Syria.
But, unfortunately, she seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding any direct criticism of the Syrian regime's leadership.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as indulgence, allowing them to intensify the struggle.
Repression so cruel that one cannot imagine for a moment that, at the same time, Syria could be elected to serve on the United Nations Human Rights Council.
the United Nations, while even today, Syrian authorities are denying UN observers access to the city of Dehra, which has been the scene of terrible violence against defenseless civilians.

Assassination within the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, and an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its own people, in contempt of the very values that the Human Rights Council is supposed to safeguard.
Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to prevent such a disaster?
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has done exquisite work on this report, and believe me, it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen the control of their borders and have succeeded in doing so.
Whether it concerns police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, or the control of air, sea, and land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only acknowledge this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now technically and personnel-wise capable of implementing this Schengen acquis.
Moreover, while no obstacles currently hinder this expansion of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be rigorously followed, especially with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece, and Turkey, as you know that the mutual trust between Schengen States is based on the full respect by these States of their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties does not fulfill its obligations, it creates vacuum effects, and the entire system becomes faulty.
I fervently hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council to welcome these two countries into the exclusive circles formed by the Schengen States.
And we will all measure, in this hemicycle, the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Once again, congratulations to Mr. Coelho for his report, Mr. President.
Mr. President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the goal of making our economy greener and our transportation more modern.
All European institutions have broadly supported this objective, including almost all member states and our Parliament.
In this context, it is regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have sought to empty the new Eurovignette directive proposal of its content and to block this file.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur, and I would like to acknowledge Saeed El Khadraoui here, thanks to his tenacity and that of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

So, while this text is certainly less ambitious than the initial proposal, it will, for the first time, enable the implementation of the polluter pays principle and the internalization of external transport costs, such as noise and CO2 emissions.

In order for this eurovignette to be more than just a tax and to effectively contribute to the improvement of transport in Europe, member states are also encouraged to reinvest the collected funds in modernizing transport modes.
The Parliament has also managed to secure concrete progress on the interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the policy objectives our institution has set for itself, I sincerely hope that we can adopt this compromise proposed to us on second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy.

Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I agree that along with liberty and fraternity, there should be equality with the farmers and countries that have returned, with the countries returning from the East.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe we have taken a significant step forward with this report.
It was not easy at first, and we were rather in a confrontational position, but we reached a consensus, and that is what matters most.
This consensus makes it possible to protect the overall project, and I believe this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We have achieved this goal, and it was not easy. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur, Mercedes, and all the Members of Parliament.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the necessity of both equality, justice, and equity among producers and among territories, and I believe this is important.
We have stated very clearly and confirmed the preservation and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms, which are essential for the quality and biodiversity of the regions.
I believe it was equally fundamental.
The fact that this concept of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page on industrial, productivist agriculture, has been incorporated into the texts is significant.
Now it will be necessary to implement this, as it is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
This is not an ideological question.
Finally, today, our concern is that there are indeed threats to the budget.
It will need to be answered clearly.

Now, what we are expecting is that we will indeed enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts and grand intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are headed, and that is what we are obviously expecting now.
I would still like to end by uttering a cry of anger against Germany's attitude, which has resulted in a reduction of food aid to the poorest in Europe by fivefold.
It was within the budget of the CAP.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest. There are 80 million European citizens who are not properly fed.
Mr. President, while the European Parliament can boast of some significant progress in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to show humility, for we are dancing on the edge of the abyss.
Let us be fully aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament remained unheard during the Greek crisis.
Whereas we are usually so quick to react to all sorts of events with resolutions around the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the Member States, and to European citizens.
The second observation pertains to the scope of this package.
By voting for what I wish, these six directives or regulations, we will undoubtedly lead the eurozone to take a step forward.
No more steps towards a discipline that has been so lacking, a step, I say, nothing more that will demonstrate its utility in the future.

But it is enough to look at the fiery debates surrounding the overturned qualified majority to gauge the distance we still have to go, when it is rules and automatic sanctions that should be the focus.
The mechanism of reversed qualified majority voting continues to act as a bogeyman for some.
We must, however, remain firm on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the benches of the left continue to reject the principles of sound budgetary management against all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are contradictory.

Yes, states must also manage their budgets prudently, like a good father managing his household, but not through public spending stimulus. It is a sweet poison in the short term, but it is never a sustainable solution.
As the next few weeks prove crucial, it is imperative today to refound an Economic Union.
This morning, after three years of work, we voted on a text that is highly significant for the advancement of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online shopping, which may well account for 25% of all commerce in Europe within twenty years, a truly significant figure.
These partnerships will be particularly transnational.
They will enable consumers to expand their choices and also pay much less.
This is a genuine progress.
For SMEs and all artisans, this is also a very important opportunity to expand their market reach.

Among the key advancements, I would like to highlight two: the extension of the cancellation period to fourteen days, and the summary of all information and the total price to be paid before finalizing the order.

And finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, along with all our colleagues, voted unanimously across all political groups, because on such a topic, what we needed was not controversy, but clearly consensus.
It is we who obtained it.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, I would like to begin by commending our colleague Carlos Coelho for his efforts on this very complex file, which requires great technical expertise, extensive work, and in-depth knowledge of the subject matter.
The control of our shared territory and European borders is one of the most significant challenges we must address, and technological tools are more than ever at the service of this endeavor.
Indeed, in recent years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some refer to as a digital tsunami is certainly expected to materialize in the coming years.
SIS, VIS, and EURODAC are all essential tools today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring effective operational management of these databases is therefore a key issue for which it is our responsibility to provide an efficient solution.

This response is of course highly sensitive and Carlos Cuello had to overcome numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political, and technical obstacles. Despite all this, he has achieved a balanced text that satisfies all interested parties.
The establishment of this network agency indeed appears to be the best solution to ensure the internal security of the Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could currently assume responsibility for the proper management of these information systems.

It will enhance the management of existing information systems, provide better synergy between these databases, and additionally allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this file was the location of the agency's headquarters. Where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have volunteered to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen information system in Strasbourg, for which it has been responsible for operational management and administration since 1995, and consequently has full technical control.
Following the conclusions of the European Council of December 2003, which gave priority to the new Member States, Estonia also wished to host this future agency.

Mr. President, it seems to me that the compromise reached is excellent. A sort of division of labor, Madam President, has been achieved by transferring the agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.

The cost-effectiveness ratio is well-balanced, and this compromise solution does not in any way jeopardize the centralized management of IT systems. Madam President, I am very pleased to have discussed this report with you.
Mr. President, the cross-cutting social clause and Article 14 of the Treaty of Lisbon bindingly guarantee social rights, including in particular the right of access to services of general interest.
It is time to prove to European citizens that social Europe is on the move.

Therefore, we must afford our social rights the full recognition they deserve within EU law, acknowledging the specific nature of SSI (Social and Solidarity-based Initiatives) in relation to competition rules. These initiatives have strong local roots and are driven by social economy actors.

Mr. De Rossa's report provides an opportunity to affirm the simple yet powerful and meaningful principles of equality, universality, and access to these collectively organized services, which are drivers of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said it was time to move to the practical aspects.
Yes, it is time to move towards concrete action, so in this debate, I propose that we genuinely support a European legislative instrument for social welfare services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution submitted by the Green Group.
Mr. President, debates concerning GMOs must imperatively be based on irrevocable arguments, both from a scientific and legal standpoint.
From a legal standpoint, member states wishing to restrict or ban GMOs on their territory needed arguments that were as varied as they were strong.
The rapporteur has expanded the range of options, yet it is still a soft measure.
- I don't know.
This basic scientific file must also be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly challenged the EFSA's scientific assessments, which are always positive about GMOs, unlike national scientific evaluations.

To restore trust, Commissioner, wouldn't it be necessary, as a first step, to simply apply the existing legislation, which aims to provide a significant number of scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council's recommendations of October 2008 remained a dead letter?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, first and foremost, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Busuttil for the outstanding work he has achieved.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal, and we can only congratulate him for it.
This report outlines an agency with enhanced capabilities, better aligned with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States, and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex is finally being given the resources to fulfill its mandates.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and avail of the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and highly efficient.
New tasks are also assigned to it, such as organizing voluntary returns and processing personal data, so that we can combat cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's scope of responsibilities empowers us to address and consider migration issues through a comprehensive approach, rather than being limited to mere mechanical border management.
I approve of the possibility of sharing personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has fully asserted itself in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an advisory council within the Agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal, which represents a step forward in achieving a healthy and responsible management of our external borders, especially in the current context of continuous and intense migratory pressures. I thank you for it.

Mr. President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Meyer, and my colleagues for their comments, sometimes critical, but this 2010 activity report is finally a remarkable opportunity to discuss the Committee on Petitions, as it remains largely unknown.
Yet it is the Commission, with a direct, sometimes physical, link to the citizen, who can attend our debates in person.
She has undeniable legitimacy in Parliament, as well as a great deal of expertise, thanks to her direct connection with the citizenry.
Indeed, any petitioner may go to the Parliament and defend their rights before the Committee on Petitions.
One can also commend the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases often addressed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be: attentive to its citizens' problems and united in finding solutions to protect them.
Unfortunately, the means of intervention and influence remain limited, particularly regarding the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes nearly completed.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will be conducting a mission on this very subject in November.
I also regret that national authorities do not always expedite the provision of all necessary information to us.
I would like to thank the European Commission for its research and verification work, even if sometimes it could go further in the pursuit of truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are doing with the European Ombudsman.
I finally call on citizens to continue to petition us as directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness as it is our responsibility to underscore its extreme urgency.
Let us first acknowledge that what was a priority yesterday remains so today, in an even more compelling manner.

The lack of definition and reliable statistical indicators on homelessness cannot prevent us from noting the alarming rise in the number of people living below the poverty line, which, according to Eurostat, increased from 79 million in 2009 to 84 million, an estimate for 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned with eradicating poverty, called on Member States to end the problem of STIs by 2015.
Today, we have moved a little closer to our goal.
Did the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, truly allow member states to concretely address the significant precariousness whose urgency has become permanent?
I truly allow myself to doubt it, and I deeply regret it.

To conclude, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy on homelessness, because of course, there is misery and lack of housing, certainly, but there are also family problems, health issues, various addictions, and personal vulnerabilities.
A comprehensive, effective, and ambitious yet tailored approach is required, one that takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their paths, and the disruptions in their lives.
This is a fundamental right, at the very least, from which a significant number of highly precarious individuals are excluded.
Madam President, as everyone has stated in recent years, the European Union has been struck by unprecedented disasters, and the cities mentioned here would take up all the debate time.
I will still cite the Azed F explosion, whose tenth anniversary we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A strengthened reaction at the European level, as proposed in Mrs. Gardini's report, represents a real opportunity to demonstrate solidarity among our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been attempting to make this pooling of our efforts operational, and it is now time to act together and no longer wait for a new catastrophe to strike our territories before learning from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our physical, human, and financial resources available to all, in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, earlier you said that we need to anticipate risks.

And it is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding from the GMES satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential instrument for disaster prevention and response coordination.
I urgently call on the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programmes that undeniably add value to Europe.

Here is the English translation:

I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her excellent report.
I hope we will adopt it, as it will pave the way for European solidarity in the service of the citizen. Thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people continues to rise within the European Union.
Over 43 million Europeans are at risk of food poverty.
The hour is grave.
Today, six member states wish to end the food aid program without any replacement solution: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and the Czech Republic.
Indeed, there is a decision by the Court of Justice, and we must respect it.
However, Mr. Commissioner, the Parliament called on you last July, at the initiative of our Green group, and you made relevant proposals to save the program.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but given that millions of people depend on this system, we cannot allow the food aid budget to be cut by four-fifths.
The emergency is real.

If nothing is done by the end of the year, food banks will be facing a shortage of over 300 million euros, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to step in and fill this gap.
This is thus a real question of solidarity among peoples.
Let us not allow a minority of irresponsible governments to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, as this is first and foremost a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change our production methods to bring food production closer to the people, especially the poorest among us, who are also entitled to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will enable us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must come to its senses and allow those in need to avail themselves of this vital aid.
I am addressing in particular the future Danish government, which will have the responsibility of ensuring the presidency of the European Union as of January.
Must we have food riots in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our approach?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council knows how to find solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, suddenly no one is available. The Parliament delivered a strong message last time: Human beings are more important than finance.
In terms of finance, it is high time to reaffirm this.
In any case, we will remain very vigilant and will not fail to renew our constructive appeal.
Indeed, six member states hold the fate of 18 million needy Europeans in their hands.
Six Member States that claim to be doing no more and no less than adhering to the letter of the law.
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm bells sounded by the associations that aid the most vulnerable?

And we, European Parliament members, representatives of all citizens, do we want an Europe where national selfishness sets the policies, paying little regard to the citizens of states in budgetary distress?
There is no question of renationalizing this aid.
No, let's maintain this program, give it a stronger legal basis, but do not abandon those who, right now, in 2012, are counting on this support during a particularly severe crisis.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I will not dwell on the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and in particular in Belgium, in Lige, ultimately resulting in hundreds of direct redundancies and jeopardizing several thousand indirect jobs.
As a native of Lige, I share the astonishment and despair of the 581 workers and their families who have been laid off.
But I also think of the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany, and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited are always the same: poor prospects for the evolution of the steel market in Europe, and strong competition from imports from China and Korea.
Russia and Brazil, the shrinking of the automotive market, and finally, the competitiveness gap, for example, of the Lige site compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
Alongside this, and despite a challenging 2010, the financial center of the Belgian steel group Arcelor Mittal generated a profit of 1 billion 394 million euros.
He paid zero euros in taxes, which corresponds to a tax rate of zero.
This is particularly shocking.
Group management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy practiced across multiple sites.
The closure of sites is nothing more in the minds of these leaders than an economic adjustment variable where human concerns are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable.
You spoke, Commissioner, of the rules.
Would it not be time for the Commission to develop a binding social responsibility code for multinational corporations?

For six years now, our Parliament has adopted a report concerning offshoring, the corporate code of conduct, the reimbursement of subsidies, and mandatory consultation between businesses, trade unions, and public authorities.
Since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission plan to do about this and within what timeframe?
While it is necessary to support the competitiveness of businesses and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, it is also essential to adopt a legislative framework.
a strong European approach to tackle delocalisations and restructurations and ensure full consideration of another form of capital, human capital.
Finally, regarding the Lige site, I hope it can benefit from the intervention of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to compensate the laid-off workers. Thank you.

Madam President, dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs hitting workers across Europe must lead us to reflect on the role we, as policymakers, have to play in the face of multinational corporations acting with impunity.

without any social ethics, which carries out stock market layoffs and offshores to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and please rating agencies at the expense of social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of September 20th on the future of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, the Parliament clearly expressed its willingness to support, above all, employees affected by the negative impacts of restructuring.
But we also asked the Commission to ensure coherence between EFSI interventions and the European Union's industrial policy, particularly through the use of structural funds.

We also insisted that the future EFG regulation include improvements so that the Fund does not produce the same random, moral effects on multinational companies as it does today, as seen in the cases of ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look at the issue of structural funds and the Globalization Adjustment Fund in isolation.
without taking into account the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them, without examining the cost-benefit ratio of a policy, I reiterate.
Mr. President, the European Ombudsman brilliantly conducts investigations into complaints lodged against the institutions and bodies of the European Union.

This instrument is necessary to facilitate free movement, for our businesses and citizens alike, but it also serves as a powerful guarantee, especially in the face of the Union's detractors who all too often claim that the European Union is merely a bureaucratic machine devoid of control.
It is clearly nonsensical. Europe is doing genuine work on itself, thanks in particular to the European Mediators.
But let me relay a finding that I deeply regret, one in which the Commission is under heavy criticism.
Firstly, there are the figures 65 and the actual figure, not 12, relating to the open inquiries initiated by the Ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also representatives from numerous companies who come to us to express their misunderstanding regarding the Commission, a European Commission that remains deaf to their requests, particularly concerning access to documents. Similarly, regarding the issue of transparency in decision-making.
Few people find their way there.
And finally, from personal experience, I must admit that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain services of the European Commission present in the Committee on Petitions.
As you know, the European Commission provides us with its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens that we see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer questions from an MEP or who take refuge in bureaucratic language almost as well as politicians and present themselves to citizens advocating their cause.

I therefore wished to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative issues addressed and resolved by the Ombudsman lie Europeans relieved to be heard but disappointed by
This behavior of citizens, then negatively marked by their confrontation with institutions, may create a feeling of revolt, incomprehension, and ultimately, perhaps, Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the Ombudsman against institutions in general are heeded. Thank you.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and the competitiveness of our European Union, these are indeed the terms in which today's subject is framed.
We, the EPP group, have lent our support to the report of our colleague, Mrs McLaughlin, to the drafting of which we contributed significantly, and we obviously support it.

This is the main recommendation of this report for greater professional mobility, more simplification and efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while ensuring patient safety and consumer protection.
But it is indeed in terms of the path to growth that the issue of increasing professional mobility arises.
Moreover, the Forum for a Single Market, held in Krakow at the beginning of October, did not err in this regard.

who recalled that Member States needed to recognize the potential of the internal market to boost growth and job creation, and that they must act to remove all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
The European Council of October 23rd last also set as one of the essential priorities for achieving smart, sustainable growth.
This primarily involves implementing the twelve priority proposals of the Single Market Act, the twelve proposals made by the Commission, which include the recognition of professional qualifications.

It is through increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unlock the growth potential contained within the internal market, our internal market of 500 million inhabitants, 500 million consumers.

Professional mobility should thus enable us to ensure, by strengthening, modernizing, and improving it, the free movement of our fellow citizens within this market, and also, we hope, to gain additional growth margins.
That is why we, in particular, wish to emphasize a practical recommendation: we, PPE, have specifically supported the implementation of a voluntary prepositioning policy.
Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Cashmarck, on his excellent work.
I would like to stress the importance of the European Parliament conducting an annual review of the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly.
This assembly plays a pivotal role in strengthening North-South dialogue and in establishing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year 2010 was a significant one for the PPE, which convened twice, as previous speakers mentioned, in Spain and the DRC, to engage in exchanges focusing on, among other things,
on the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, or still on the freedom and independence of the media and food security.
But in 2010, the EPP also sent its first election observation mission of this legislative term.
I had the honour of co-chairing this mission in Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Assaride, a member of parliament from Mali.
This election observation mission was an outright success.

We were able to meet with all the concerned political actors, and thanks to the dual origin of this ACP delegation, both Caribbean and European, we embodied a legitimacy distinct from European or African missions.
I therefore invite the PPE Bureau to renew this experience, which allows us to put into practice the solidarity and special relations that bind the European Union to the ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Dardenne for his very interesting report.
Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, for our fellow citizens, it is a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people living in precarious situations by 20 million by 2020 requires strong measures involving different levels of public authority.

We must, now more than ever, uphold the commitments made by the European Union in 2010, during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion and at the launch of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion, to establish a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must secure and optimize European funds, including the aid program for the most deprived, which is currently being maintained, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent persons.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought at the horizontal level, and it is now time to act to enable the most disadvantaged to escape their precariousness.

And we, as policymakers, at the European, national, and local levels, must take the necessary measures to ensure them, without discrimination, access to housing, access to healthcare, access to justice, access to education, and access to a first job with a minimum income that can be indexed according to the poverty rate of each Member State.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation, as well as in poverty reduction, will enable us to implement a sustainable, smart, and inclusive growth strategy.
The Europe we wish for and need today is a Europe of solidarity.
Mr. President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms. Levin, for her excellent work.

As the draftsperson for the Development Committee's opinion, I am pleased that the Fisheries Committee has incorporated the elements contained in our opinion, as it is crucial that the development dimension be taken into account.
be taken into account in measures to combat illegal fishing globally, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, combating illegal fishing requires global solutions and the involvement of all states, including developing countries.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capacities of states are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, the same constraints cannot be imposed on developed or developing countries without accompanying measures.
Small island states, for instance, have very limited capacities.
Therefore, we must support their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
That is why the Union must increase the financial envelope for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this field with developing countries.

Moreover, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing be implemented, as this practice undermines the development of countries by reducing the financial resources they could derive from fishing economic activity.
Now, these resources are essential for developing countries to implement social, economic, and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, promote the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the recipient states of the aid.
Adopting a holistic approach is necessary to stem the plague of illegal fishing. Thank you.
Mr. President, I would like to say that, largely thanks to these ultra-peripheral regions, the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.
This is a major asset for Europe, hence the elaboration and implementation of a comprehensive policy for the sea, oceans, and the deep sea are essential for the future.
But I fear that with 20 or 50 million euros, it will not be necessary, sufficient to achieve this great challenge.

Combating illegal fishing is part of this broader policy, and it is urgent, at the European level, to find an adequate solution to this problem, particularly within the framework of international cooperation.
I also draw attention to the fact that the maritime zones of Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte, and Runion are regularly violated and plundered.
As the report does not mention it, I take this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this specific issue.
Madam President, I would like to begin by acknowledging the Polish presidency, which has demonstrated dynamism and determination.
Next week, at the Council, our heads of state and government will have to make essential decisions for the future of the eurozone, for the future of the Union.
They will also have to seriously address the issue of reviving growth.

In saying this, we clearly see that today, financial stability has become the top priority, and the pressures, the tensions exerted from the outside on the countries of the eurozone, but also within the eurozone, are undermining our credibility and eroding confidence.
To hope for the return of confidence, it is necessary to restore financial stability, halt the terrible progression of national deficits and sovereign debts.
Financial stability has indeed become the top priority, it has become an urgent obligation for all.

Our democracies have, in fact, all embarked on very courageous programs to sanitize their public finances and reduce their debt. However, financial stability is also a prerequisite for any resumption of growth.
But whoever speaks of solidarity, whoever speaks of financial stability, budgetary discipline because they go hand in hand, of course, must also speak of solidarity.
It seems important to us to ensure this dual movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline, and solidarity.
A final word on democracy.
Be careful not to undermine our democratic institutions.
Rather than contemplating the use of a judicial mechanism to penalize budgetary deviations, I would suggest that we focus on control and sanction mechanisms exercised by democratic institutions.

To be perfectly honest, I am not the spokesperson for the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, and, quite frankly, even though I belong to the same political party as him, I am not, so to speak, constantly in a position to relay the statements of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs.
To be perfectly honest once again, I am not aware of any recent statements by Alain Jupp to that effect.
I simply think that France's current position is to continually reaffirm that the euro is truly at the heart of our European construction, that safeguarding the euro,

I wish to speak of the preservation of this shared project and the safeguarding of the European Union. In this movement to protect the euro, we must of course think about the future, consider the protection of future generations, and the maintenance of peace on our continent.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, tomorrow we will be voting for the third time on the new development cooperation instrument.
the development, which includes accompanying measures in the banana sector for ACP banana-exporting countries, following the reduction of their tariff preferences, the BAM.

I strongly regret that all of Parliament's demands regarding the application of delegated acts have not been incorporated into this instrument.

The Commission also issued a statement detailing the methodology employed.
Furthermore, we have a Council declaration on the next Multiannual Financial Framework stating that it will duly take into account delegated acts in external aid instruments after 2013.
Finally, in its resolution, the Parliament clarifies, and this point seems crucial to me, that this is by no means a precedent.

And I would like to tell you that I am back from Togo, where the 22nd session of the ACP-EU APP took place, and I believe I can say to you that our ACP friends are counting on us given the urgency of the situation.
The funds should have been unlocked two years ago.
We must be aware of the deplorable consequences for our ACP partners if the BAM ICD were to be rejected.
The situation of certain farmers is dramatic; we can no longer wait and must act accordingly.
I am counting on you to support the text. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, our coordinator, Tissbergmann, is unfortunately unable to be present this evening due to personal reasons.
However, I know that he fully shares my analysis on this matter.

The conciliation on this legislative package was lengthy and tedious, and while the result on human rights instruments and ICI plus is satisfactory, we are far from done regarding the banana instrument.

Thus, the compromise reached on this text dismisses out of hand the mandate given to our negotiating team, which was to place Parliament on an equal footing with the Council in all programming decisions regarding the choice of strategic priorities and financial allocations.
For it is indeed the powers of our Assembly and the very spirit of the Treaty of Lisbon that are at stake here.
The selection of programming priorities is a highly political decision on which our Assembly must have a say.
By categorically refusing to acknowledge any oversight power to the Parliament and employing shameful blackmail, the Council has, once again, demonstrated a reprehensible ideological retreat.
But member states must understand that the external action of the European Union is now a shared competence between our institutions.
That is why our Parliament must remain sovereign and reject the proposal on the banana instrument.
This is the only way we can demonstrate to the Council and the Commission that Parliament desires greater transparency in Community decisions.
If we lose this battle, the absurdity would be that we would have to wait for a new treaty to finally obtain the powers that the Lisbon Treaty already provides.
Mr. President, at the risk of shocking the most federalist among you, I believe that defense policy is inherently a national policy.
It responds to the strategic, diplomatic, and security needs specific to each nation.
Capacity sharing is nothing more than a sovereignty amputation. The single market for military equipment is a grand joke when certain member states believe that
Defense is secured in Washington, primarily equipped with American materials, as Europe is unable, in this field as in so many others, to enforce community preference.
Regarding the common security challenges of the Member States of the Union, there is nothing that cannot be resolved through intergovernmental cooperation, without any intervention from Brussels.

I am sorry, but entrusting these areas to Mrs Ashton would be tantamount to acknowledging that Moody's and Standard & Poor's have legitimacy in judging our economic policies, and accepting that the Mercosur duo could impose a purely German Europe on twenty-seven peoples, which is a mental aberration.

For thirty years, and even more so since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defense budgets have been the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary rigor, to the point of rendering most of our military tools obsolete.

deficient or obsolete, all in the name of purely financial considerations, with each expecting the neighbor or the supposed big American brother to make the efforts they are no longer willing to make themselves.
But you are mistaken about the voice.

It is only by returning to independent and resolute national policies that we can individually equip ourselves with the necessary means not only for our national security and interests, but also for the cooperation of these means to address common challenges.
A collection of weaknesses and gaps has never amounted to a strength.

Mr. President, I wished to bring the support of the French delegation of the EPP group to the treaty on stability, coordination, and European economic governance, and its support for the main conclusions reached by the Council.
Let us not be mistaken.
This treaty represents a significant step towards greater economic and budgetary integration, towards more financial stability.
Let's repeat that here.
There can be no sustainable rebound in growth and employment without the sound management of our public finances.
Of course, growth is not decreed; it is not a single treaty that can revive growth on its own.
But a treaty, that is, a set of rules and mutual commitments, can bring trust and accountability.

As the chairman of the Socialist group saw fit to introduce partisan politics into this chamber and, in referring to the upcoming French presidential campaign, mentioning the Socialist candidate in this French presidential election, I wished to respond.

renegotiate what and with whom.

Madame Ashton, Madagascar, one of the poorest countries in the world, is experiencing a political crisis whose resolution hinges on the implementation of the roadmap leading up to presidential and legislative elections.
The intersection of these factors in this country is negative.
In normal times, our contribution approximates 50% of this country's budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budget support for the ninth and tenth EDF funds, but not for the MDGs.
During this time, the population suffers and businesses operating in Madagascar are sometimes involuntarily called upon to contribute.

While supporting your position, we urge you to use your full influence within SADC to ensure that the legal and judicial entanglement regarding the return of the former president is resolved as soon as possible, as it is one of the most sensitive elements in the implementation of this roadmap.

I would appreciate your opinion on this matter, and I also wish to inform you that the European Union-Madagascar Friendship Group, which we have just established in the European Parliament, is ready to work with you and the Commission in the interests of the Malagasy people and in defense of our Union's values.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to commend the rapporteur, Mr. Iturguys, for the quality of his work, the lengthy negotiation process he had to lead, and the patience he demonstrated.
We finally come to the vote on this report, which is extremely important, as it allows us to bring the difficulties and concerns of our fellow citizens to this House, the Commission, and the Council.
This is further proof, if any were needed, of the effectiveness of the right of petition in Europe.
Petitions concerning the environment are predominant, and waste is a significant concern among our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a societal issue.
We consume in Tuva.
We are only now realizing that what we do not consume, we throw away.
This awareness must be absolutely strengthened among citizens, clearly.
But this report also serves as a reminder to Member States.
It is nonetheless concerning to see that the states appear to be unable to control the situation.
Only six member states have transposed the Waste Framework Directive in time.
The number of complaints received on this subject sometimes demonstrates a lack of transparency in the selection of landfill sites.
Finally, and this is the most concerning, organized crime appears to be doing as it pleases.
A market worth 75 billion euros will inevitably attract covetousness.
States must send a strong signal.
There must be increased penalties for companies that abuse public contracts for personal gain.
This report serves as a warning signal to states, but the European Commission must also fulfill its role and ensure the proper implementation of waste directives.
This file must be made visible, but also credible.
If no one cooperates, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and cross-verification processes that could drag on for years.
Let us heed the petitioners' message and halt this mess more swiftly.
Ladies and gentlemen, the Commissioner, the rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate Mr Nicholson for the courage he displayed before the Council and the Commission.
Despite this, I fear that what we have achieved does not allow for a balance between producers and industry.
This agreement reminds me of that illusion we know, recounted by children, of a paradise where vegetarian lions would eat grass alongside sheep.
I don't believe it for a second. Since 2003, Ms. Fischer Boel has done everything in her power to ideologically destroy milk quotas.
In October 2009, the Court of Auditors, despite everything, recognized the effectiveness of these milk quotas.

Now, today, we find ourselves in an even more dramatic situation, as we are witnessing in Denmark currently, where the most solid farms, due to increased production, are all facing bankruptcy, with a 40% drop in land prices.
Do we want this for the European level?
I say no, we need to control production with the involvement of public authorities. Thank you.
Madam Commissioner, the data protection standards of third countries still differ significantly from European standards.
It is, however, our duty to ensure that our prevailing European minimum standards of protection are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data are processed fairly and collected for specified, legitimate purposes.

European citizens must be able to enjoy a guaranteed right of access to and rectification of their personal data, as well as the right to initiate legal proceedings in the event of a violation of their rights.
Action is required to enable European and international standards to coexist and resolve a legal conflict that could be detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not sufficient.
It must be intelligently articulated and coexist with international standards, as we cannot shirk our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation resonates with other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European program for monitoring the financing of terrorism.
Such a system would provide us with a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and thus the protection of personal data of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully uphold their protection standards. Thank you.
Mr. President, first of all, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent over a year strengthening its economic governance to prevent macroeconomic imbalances and excessive budget deficits that threaten the European economy. However, this has not prevented social exclusion or the rise in unemployment.
It is time, in fact, it is now urgent that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy become an absolute priority for the European Commission and for the Member States, with a view to growth.

Each country will need to implement a national employment plan, which means that the focus should be on various topics such as integration, training, retraining, microcredit, apprenticeships, paid internships, and so on.

Now, as Commissioner Andor reminded us earlier, we have 23 million unemployed people in Europe, but also 23 million SMEs and 23 billion euros in European funds dedicated to employment that are unused.
We could almost make this into a strategy 23
And that's not including the 60 billion euros in unallocated cohesion funds.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been implemented and have proven effective, based on the principle of flexicurity.
So let's draw inspiration from it.

This also means that our social policy, as a whole, must be better adapted, with more advantageous social incentives than those linked to unemployment, and active support for all socially virtuous enterprises.
We had poverty reduction targets to meet by 2020, but we already know that these will not be achieved due to the lack of strong and appropriate measures taken by member states.

Our role as parliamentarians must be fully realized, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy expended on implementing robust economic governance measures also be directed towards ambitious, effective, and binding social governance measures.
Madam President, undeniably, the women's cause owes much to Europe.
The principle of equality between men and women was already enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and has been continually reaffirmed since in numerous treaties.
Gender equality is indeed a fundamental value of our European project.
As a result, Europe has consistently worked in a very proactive manner for gender equality and for the advancement of women.
Gradually, progress was made.
Numerous legislative instruments have been adopted, and directives have been established.
Right here, within our Parliament, there has existed for many years an extremely active and vigilant Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality.
A European Institute for Gender Equality has been established.
Programs are implemented, and financial resources are allocated year after year.
More recently, on March 2nd, we had the opportunity to celebrate the second edition of the European Day for Equal Treatment and Equal Pay.
a European Equal Pay Day. Undeniably, the legislative framework exists, and European commitment has been demonstrated on multiple occasions.
However, it must be acknowledged that the struggle remains as relevant as everthe struggle for gender equality, and in particular, for equal pay.
There is always, on average, across the countries of the European Union, a wage gap of the order of
For equal work, women still earn 17% less than men.
This is, of course, completely unacceptable.
The Women's Committee of the Parliament is currently working on a draft resolution to call on the European Commission to revise the 2006 directive on women's equality.
The treatment, which is one of the most concerning battles and at the very heart of the worries and claims of European women in all our societies.

On another subject, that of the establishment of quotas, quotas both within the decision-making bodies of large companies and within political life, I come from a country, France, which adopted them a long time ago, back in
ten years, binding rules on quotas in political life and, more recently, about a year ago, a law to introduce quotas on the boards of directors of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have opted for such legislations.
What is the assessment after a few years of implementation in one case, and a few months in another, when we are forced to acknowledge that things have moved forward, that progress has been made?
So, a necessary evil.
Quotas have an impact.

Madam Commissioner, you have recently taken a significant step towards establishing European-level quotas in the decision-making bodies of large companies by launching this extensive public consultation to gather opinions on the actions to be implemented, potentially including legislative measures.
On this matter, you will have my full and unwavering support.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, on the occasion of this resolution, allow me to address two topics. Firstly, the issue of water management globally and in Europe.
an Europe and then a question to the European Commission so that actions can be taken to address a number of our concerns related to the Common Agricultural Policy.
The issue, as we know, is that water is the great concern of the twenty-first century.
It is because we will have answers that we will have peace in the world and in Europe.
We are aware of the challenges, the challenges in terms of management, and the challenges in terms of food security.
And, on the occasion of this forum, as our colleague Rivasi reminded us, too many purely commercial concerns lie at the heart of the discussion that has taken place in Marseille in recent days.
A question: why is there no coherence between water management and water-related resources and the common agricultural policy?
Nothing in the CAP reform indicates how this management will be handled, as our colleague Sarboud mentioned earlier.
Give us answers.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank the rapporteur and our assistants for their work.
This report now very aptly bears its name, namely, removing barriers to citizenship.
Europe is a remarkable project, but it is all too often noted that it remains ill-defined.
Let's take the economic crisis as an example.
She brought to light our weaknesses and enabled us to build more robustly the regulatory institutions of our single market.
For the European citizen, it is the same.
The petitions committee, a true complaints bureau, records the grievances of our fellow citizens every day.
In three days, the European Citizens' Initiative will complement this framework.
Despite all our policies advocating for mobility, adherence, European values, and exchanges, there are still far too many obstacles to the exercise of citizenship.
A citizen who does not feel European is a citizen who will not go to vote, one who does not see the relevance that Europe holds in their daily life.
Together with my colleagues from the EPP, we have put forward a great many proposals, more than any other group, and I would like to thank them for their efforts.
This is a report that aims to foster a sense of European belonging and identity, which we must recreate and nurture through these measures.
Our Europe must be a protective Europe.
Commissioner Viviane Reding has put forward twenty-five very concrete proposals in support of citizens.
They are essential for restoring trust between the citizen and Europe.
But the proposals contained in this report reflect other expectations of our fellow citizens: online shopping, moving, children's rights, employment, health, and safety.
citizen participation, healthcare abroad, twinning initiatives, minority rights, etc. We still struggle too much to fully benefit from the opportunities offered by Europe.
Rights are exercised, claims are heard.
We are the relays here.
The European Year of Citizenship in 2013 must demonstrate to citizens that, along with free movement, there is also a free use of rights in Europe.
Mr. President, I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for changing behaviors.

I believe that energy consumption should be aligned with an indicative price signal for consumers. Moreover, I maintain that, to prevent any distortions in the internal market, we must strive to harmonize our tax practices.
The principle of proportionality among the different levels of taxation on energy products seems to me to be a necessity.
In the case at hand, for instance, this would put an end to the diesel tourism we are currently witnessing, which is not an acceptable phenomenon.
I therefore share the philosophy of the Commission's proposal for a revised directive.

However, if we are to achieve our goals in terms of reducing CO2 emissions or improving energy efficiency, our collective decisions must also avoid penalizing citizens or sectors that are particularly vulnerable to pollution.

The volatility of prices on global markets, and I think of the agricultural sector, for example. The proposed directive will have an impact, certainly differentiated according to the tax level of each Member State, but an impact nonetheless on the price of diesel.
The question is, ultimately, who will bear the brunt of this price increase?
Are there any real, practicable, and accessible alternatives for consumers?
As a shadow rapporteur on the Environment Committee, I support an ambitious yet above all sustainable position for all.

I therefore advocate for a more gradual approach and for the entry into force of the proposal and its principle of proportionality by 2030, subject to a new impact assessment that updates the one on which the Commission relied, which was nevertheless conducted five years ago.

One month ago, in this very place, we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe due to the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational present in nine European Union member states and which is restructuring its production facilities in Europe in the face of declining steel demand.
With the shutdown of two blast furnaces in Belgium and Luxembourg, and the idling of a blast furnace in France, it is estimated that nearly 6 direct jobs will be at risk in 2012.

Beyond unacceptable practices, such as stop and go, which should be better regulated, it is the broader question of European steelmaking and adaptation to change that requires extremely urgent responses.

Six months ago, the Commission informed us of the need, in light of the economic crisis, to conduct a new consultation exercise for the responsible management of restructuring with social partners and public authorities.
My question is straightforward: six months later, where do we stand?

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I would like to put an end to the unfounded allegations of the circulation in France of 500,000 to one million fake biometric passports that are said to be in circulation in our country.
France takes the risks of fraud related to identity documents very seriously.
It does not take infractions in this matter lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is an offense punishable by one year in prison and a fine of 15 euros.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, enabling prefectures to allocate additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, a fraud liaison officer is appointed.
Furthermore, the security measures for issuing identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, the civil status data provided can be cross-checked between administrative services, preferably via dematerialized means, in order to minimize the risk of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to the residential address verification trap.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path towards enhanced security for proof of residence documents through the inclusion of a barcode.

The classic treatment of a title request includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents produced in previous title requests, and the possible authentication of supporting documents.

The secure issuance of titles is further guaranteed by the double appearance of the applicant at the time of filing the application and subsequently at the time of collecting the title, as well as by the taking of two digital fingerprints.
And this is without mentioning the enhanced checks for the renewal of lost and stolen documents for comparative purposes with the data held by the prefectures. I conclude.
Furthermore, France informs international cooperation bodies, notably Interpol, of issued, lost, and stolen passports to prevent their fraudulent use.
Dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, firstly, it is evident that our fellow citizens are increasingly seeking to find and consume locally produced and seasonal food for health and quality reasons, among others.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and swiftly to this growing demand.

We must support the development of local infrastructures for producers, such as maintaining local slaughterhouses which, while ensuring rigorous health controls, enable the growth of local short-circuit supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers market their products and raise awareness among consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will enable farmers to retain a larger portion of the added value generated on their farms.

It is necessary to promote and facilitate direct sales on the farm and to support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points, thereby offering local consumers a wider range of products.

The European Commission should facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct sales systems through delivery to consumers, such as the AMAP (Association for the Maintenance of Peasant Agriculture) in France, which enables nearly 3 farmers to supply 60 families.
Finally, member states must be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning farm size, production volume, or the traditional nature of the product, to define local agriculture.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am pleased that this amending budget concerning ITER funding, which has been voted on, received a large majority in the Budgets Committee on March 29th.
By funding this additional cost, we avoid abandoning a strategic fundamental research project in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.
Let us recall that none of the seven partners in the Euratom community has called into question its overall contribution to the project.
Japan, despite the Fukushima disaster, has decided to scrupulously honor its budgetary commitments to ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work, and the ITER project would have faced detrimental delays.
Today, a thousand people work for ITER in Kadara.
From 2015 until 2017, the construction phase of the buildings and the assembly of the machine could employ up to 4 people on this site.
In conclusion, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, thank you for the work we have accomplished together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a shared political vision for the major environmental challenges up to 2020 and beyond.
This is why it is so important to launch a seventh environmental action program, by synergizing existing financial frameworks and mobilizing new funding resources.
This program must ensure consistency and alignment between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture,
Fishing, research and innovation, health, transportation, regional development, territorial planning, and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is affecting the European Union, we must not give in to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate realm.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, especially regarding the efficient use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in sustainable economy and eco-innovation, which are sources of growth, competitiveness, and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote ecodesign, recycling, but also the environmental labeling of products in order to avoid waste and poor consumer choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental pedagogy, essential for European citizens.
The environmental action program is a political policy instrument, but it is also a communication tool.

It must provide the necessary readability and predictability for national and local administrations, citizens, but also entrepreneurs and investors, regarding the European Union's environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a straitjacket.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, in the face of the profound changes our world is undergoing today, the Union must reform its generalized system of preferences.
Like any compromise, this one does not deviate from the rule.
While it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial perspective, it is far from perfect. We must bear in mind that this regulation is intended for developing countries.
In developing its new paradigm of differentiation, the Commission states its intention to refocus its action in support of the poorest countries.

Leaving many middle-income developing countries with undiversified economies and vulnerable to climate fluctuations.

Commissioner, the issue of the availability of public consultations in the various languages of the European Union is unfortunately not a new one.

This is, in my opinion, a crucial question, which is why I have not only already submitted several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally questioned Mr. Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must adhere to the principle of equal treatment and access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its judgment of November 20, 2008.
Mr. President, I was not at all satisfied with the response from the European Commission that public consultations do not claim to provide a fully representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission acknowledges that certain positions and views may be overrepresented at the expense of others.
This is not an answer.
I am inquiring about the criteria that would enable us to measure the overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not overrepresented due to their availability in English alone, they fail in their purpose of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result provides a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we wish to maintain written consultations as a tool underpinning the legislative proposals of the European Commission, we must ensure a democratic, transparent, and fair system for all citizens.
Therefore, if the European Commission conducts written consultations, it must take responsibility and provide the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
In conclusion, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

It would also be necessary to include in the analysis the overly short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately mostly accessible to those in the know. Thank you.
The proposed regulations aim to grant the European Commission increased powers to oversee national budgets and economic policies.

States will be punished, fined, one could say spanked, with financial sanctions that will be strengthened and made more automatic.
Even if certain amendments aim to prevent solely budgetary austerity through growth measures, your proposals are merely there to sweeten the pill.
Growth, as you know, just like me, cannot be decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, following the tactic of the Chinese thief, the European bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian state has finally been established, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
