Mr. President, I would like to firstly commend the determination of the European Commission, and particularly yours, Mr. Commissioner, for tirelessly placing the revival and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

As you recalled, Commissioner, it has already been more than two years that both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to pinpoint the challenges and sectors that require more internal market integrationmore internal market for greater growth, enhanced competitiveness, and more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also eventually came to emphasize the great importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve levers for growth.
Rather than continually seeking to invent new growth instruments, we are better off working with the toolkit we already have.

We therefore take this opportunity, in the context of the resolution that will be put to a vote by our assembly tomorrow, to send a strong political message to the Member States regarding the need for greater speed and efficiency in transposing the directives already adopted.

He has embraced greater mobilization and commitment in the newly opened fields. I will cite just one example: the enhancement of workers' mobility, with improved ease of movement and smoother traffic flow.
We will welcome with great interest, Commissioner, the second stage of the act for the single market that you will present after the summer.
We will know how to demonstrate both political willpower and the ability to apply pressure on member states.
We witnessed the Mediator scandal some time ago.
We now have the breast implant scandal, which unfortunately highlights, as you have pointed out, Commissioner, the failings in European health safety.
This mammary implant scandal, these fourteen years of fraud, 1996-2010, unpunished.
There are 500 prostheses worn worldwide, 8 implant removals, and 48 confirmed cases of cancer.
Finally, there are 3 complaints filed. This number is alarming and shocking.

How, despite the warnings of the American Food and Drug Administration, the FDA, Commissioner, and the numerous complaints and lawsuits regarding prosthesis failures filed in Great Britain, France in particular, were the national and European agencies able to overlook such a fraud?
This tragedy promptly led us to consider enhancing the European system for controlling medical devices, as you just explained.
We must, Commissioner, today build a new system capable of preventing scandal, but it is a new system that we must construct.
This new legislation is announced for the fall, as you have indicated.
As a co-author of this resolution, I am, of course, satisfied with it.

So, why make an unacceptable exception for many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why not advocate for the establishment of a market authorization for class 3 medical devices, which are the highest risk?
Commissioner Dalli, could you please explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation where production has increased by more than 2.5 times, and yet industries are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England, and across European countries, prices are falling.
This means very clearly that prices are linked to the volume of production, and that production volumes and prices must be organized together.
At the same time, today, producers are victims of an increase of over 44% in the price of plant proteins and 30% in the price of cereals.
The Parliament has already voted on the necessity, here, to ensure that the added value is shared among producers and that farmers are not victims of businesses and large retailers.

I call on the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the challenge to the control of production, but at the same time, I state very clearly that Member States must clean up their own house, because there are countries that have respected the quota rules and others that have not.
It is also this that has led to these quotas being challenged.
There is, therefore, a dual responsibility: that of the Commission and that of the Member States.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I am speaking on behalf of Maurice Ponga, the Development Committee's draftsman on the Gallagher report.
It seemed important to me to recall that when a nation wishes to sanction a country that engages in unsustainable fishing practices, it must take into account its level of development.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of policy coherence for development, it is crucial, in my view, that the measures adopted on fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our Development Committee by stipulating that measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to ensure that the level of development and vulnerability of countries are duly taken into account.
The third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these sea plunderers, solely responsible for the poor health of stocks, as environmental organizations and the European Commission claim, sweeping all categories of fishing under the same umbrella.

It is understood that fish stocks must be preserved, but we must also enable our fishing sailors to make a living from their activity and protect the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
Now, the main measures of the European executive once again aim to reduce the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than 50% since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the introduction of individual transferable quotas, which are seen as a guarantee of industrialization and concentration in the sector, or even a complete ban on discards, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project likely suits the industrial fleet, but in its current state, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking Charles Goerens for his excellent report.

We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world's total official development assistance, and yet, as we approach the 2015 deadline for the MDGs, even though some targets seem to be within reach,
Affected as we are, we must ask ourselves how to improve our aid, to make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable commitments with short- and medium-term timelines.

The economic crisis, climate change, the rising power of emerging countries, and land grabbing compel us to define new priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Indeed, a European consensus exists, but we need to rethink European and international institutional systems regarding environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from organizations that effectively make decisions, such as the WTO, for instance.
Finally, and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not merely a matter of charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
One need only look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries such as China, Brazil, and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better consider the geostrategic evolution of recent years, as the emerging countries of today were, until recently, developing nations.
Henceforth, as indispensable economic powers, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at both the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join my colleagues from other groups, as well as those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, in calling for 2015 to be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Mr. President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission, in my view, raises many questions, the primary one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission intends that, starting in 2014, the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid be based on the mechanical application of the sole criterion of per capita wealth.
As Mrs Ashton reminded us, these issues are not merely accounting matters, but warrant a genuine political debate on defining our priorities in international cooperation.
Moreover, this differentiated approach, in my view, is not in keeping with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. Mr. President, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have taken a keen interest in the report by my colleague Regina Bastos, concerning the twenty main concerns of citizens and businesses.
We discussed this report, incidentally in connection with our debate on the twenty years of the internal market.
It has already been twenty years since the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital was supposed to be fully realized within our living space, exchange platform, and internal market.

I was particularly interested to note that at the forefront of the precautions expressed by our European fellow citizens is the essence of professional qualifications, and that we truly need to be especially proactive and highly effective.

This is what our fellow citizens are expecting in order to truly establish, in the very near future, procedures for recognizing their diplomas, skills, and professional qualifications that are much faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
This is a real challenge.

As the shadow rapporteur for the EPP Group on this topic, the modernization of these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO committee to genuinely address this major challenge of mobility.
For greater mobility, for more Europe, this is what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
Mr. President, this year the Committee on Petitions has acquired the right to be automatically associated for the hearing of European citizens' initiatives.
This is, for me, the strong signal of the year 2011 for this Commission.
Citizens already had a Commission to turn to in cases of breach of their rights, but this is now also the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Committee on Petitions can increasingly be seen as the citizens' privileged interlocutor in the European Parliament.
This issue of consideration is also reflected in the outcomes of the Petitions Committee's positions.
Too often, we are approached by citizens facing legal entanglements on which we wish to take a stand, but while the issues are European,
Even if solutions should be European, we remain powerless because subsidiarity still does not align with European solutions due to a lack of national will.

Mr. President, I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The issues are both national and European when custody or visitation rights cross national borders, in this case, those of Germany.
Despite the glaring difficulties for many parents in seeing their children born of binational unions, we remain in Parliament still powerless to act.

My proposal that all European citizens have the right to a national ombudsman, especially from Germany, which sends a large number of petitions based on the model of the Defender of Rights in France, has had no effect.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, it remains a conciliatory solution, a European problem, and a national solution.
In many cases, European law appears powerless to meet the expectations of citizens.
